• Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) is a popular approach for time series classification, often used with 1-Nearest Neighbor (1-NN) and global constraints like Sakoe-Chiba Band (SC Band) or Ratanamahatana-Keogh Band (RK Band).
• Euclidean distance is commonly used but DTW distance is more suitable for time series data.
• SC Band speeds up DTW calculation and acts as a global constraint, originally with a fixed width of 10% of the time series length.
• Recent work shows that the optimal SC Band width depends on the data properties, so testing all possible widths is necessary.
• RK Band generalizes the global constraint model, allowing multi-band adjustments per class.
• The original RK Band learning algorithm uses a hill-climbing search with accuracy and distance metrics, but it can suffer from overfitting.
• This paper proposes two new learning algorithms: Band Boundary Extraction and Iterative Learning, using Silhouette Index as a heuristic function.
• The final classification uses 1-NN with DTW distance and the discovered band, along with the lb_Keogh lower bound for speed-up.

<summary>
* The Standard Model (SM) of elementary particles has been successful in describing nature at the electroweak scale.
* The ATLAS and CMS collaborations at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) have discovered a new particle consistent with the SM Higgs boson, strengthening the correctness of the SM.
* No explicit evidence of physics beyond the SM has been reported from the LHC so far.
* An anomaly in the muon anomalous magnetic moment (g-2) has been consistently observed, with discrepancies between SM predictions and measured values exceeding 3σ.
* This anomaly could hint at new physics related to the muon sector, motivating the exploration of new gauge interactions for the muon beyond the SM.
* The muon could have a new gauge interaction with a new Z' boson, which would contribute to the muon's magnetic moment.
* The new Z' boson could also interact with the SM quarks and leptons, potentially affecting other processes and observables.
* The new gauge interaction must respect the constraints from electroweak precision tests and flavor physics.
* The new physics scale associated with the new gauge interaction should be high enough to avoid conflicting with the successful predictions of the SM.
</summary>

• The study investigates the dynamics of entanglement in a system of two qubits interacting with two amplitude-damping reservoirs. The entanglement is found to be redistributed among all bipartite subsystems in an invariant manner, as described by an identity that holds at any time.
• The entanglement distribution depends on the properties of the reservoir and its coupling to the qubit. In certain cases, such as when the qubit and reservoir form a bound state and non-Markovian effects are significant, the entanglement can be stably distributed among all subsystems, and entanglement sudden death (ESD) of the qubits is not always accompanied by entanglement sudden birth (ESB) of the reservoirs.

• The origin of celestial gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) is still unexplained, despite their powerful flashes and cosmological distances.
• GRBs are observed with satellites, and their afterglow emission has been discovered, with measured red shifts up to 4.5.
• Possible explanations include the collapse of a massive star (hypernova) and the coalescence of a compact binary system.
• Both scenarios predict the emission of gravitational waves (GWs), which can be detected by present resonant detectors.
• GW bursts associated with GRBs are expected to have amplitudes of the order of 10^-21 at 1 Gpc, but detection of a single event is challenging.
• The authors launched a program to study the presence of correlations between GRB events and GW signals from detectors like NAUTILUS and EXPLORER.
• They used an algorithm based on cross-correlating the outputs of two GW detectors to cope with the unknown time difference between GRB and GW bursts.
• The Rome group operates two resonant bar detectors, EXPLORER and NAUTILUS, with different resonant frequencies and bandwidths.
• The agreement between simulated input signals and calculated values using their model shows that their approach is correct.

• The paper discusses a model for citation distribution in scientific publications, focusing on two research areas and their cross-referencing.
• The model considers preferential attachment and the growth of networks over time.
• The model is analyzed using a rate equation approach, with a focus on the total number of citations and the issuing publications.
• The paper defines various parameters to describe the networks, such as the average number of nodes with total connections and the average number of nodes with incoming intra- and cross-links.
• The time evolution of the joint distribution of intra- and cross-links is described by a rate equation.
• The model is applied to the web of human sexual contacts, where males and females are considered as two coupled growing networks.
• The paper discusses the implications of the model for different complex systems and acknowledges financial support and useful discussions.

• The paper introduces the concept of shower partons and their distributions (SPDs) to represent fragmentation functions in terms of recombination.
• The SPDs are determined phenomenologically by solving integral equations that relate them to known fragmentation functions.
• The recombination model is used to describe the hadronization process, with the recombination function (RF) specified for meson formation.
• The SPDs are shown to be useful in problems where fragmentation functions alone are insufficient, such as in heavy-ion collisions and dihadron correlations in jets.
• The SPDs obtained are model-dependent but can be extended to higher transverse momenta and used in conjunction with recombination for hadron production in heavy-ion collisions at super high energies.

• **Problem Definition**: The paper considers a nonconvex semidefinite programming problem with a nonconvex matrix-valued mapping inequality constraint, which has applications in static output feedback controller design and topology optimization. The goal is to find a local optimization method to solve this problem.

• **Methodology**: The proposed method approximates the feasible set of the nonconvex problem by a sequence of inner positive semidefinite convex approximation sets. The algorithm is modified using a regularization technique to ensure strict descent. The convergence of the algorithm to a stationary point is proven under mild conditions.

• **Applications and Results**: The method is applied to several problems in static output feedback control, including spectral abscissa optimization, mixed H2/H-infinity synthesis, and sparse linear static output feedback controller design. Numerical tests show that the algorithm can find solutions for many problems in the comp@xmath254ib library, and it outperforms the convex-concave decomposition method in some cases.

• The text discusses a discrete differential geometry scheme for fermionic field theories, focusing on the Dirac-Kähler formulation.
• The scheme uses two parallel lattices to maintain locality of the Hodge star operator and a finite element scheme for the wedge product.
• The paper aims to apply this scheme to the Dirac-Kähler formulation and study its implications for chiral symmetry and flavor projection.

• **Cognitive Radio Network and Eavesdropping**: The text discusses cognitive radio networks, which allow secondary users to transmit on the same frequency band as primary users, as long as interference is kept below a certain limit. It also highlights the vulnerability of wireless communications to eavesdropping.
• **Wyner's Wiretap Channel and Secrecy Capacity**: The problem of secure transmission in the presence of an eavesdropper was first studied by Wyner, who defined secrecy capacity as the maximum achievable rate from the transmitter to the legitimate receiver while keeping the eavesdropper ignorant of the transmitted messages.
• **Cognitive Radio and Information-Theoretic Security**: While cognitive radio networks are susceptible to eavesdropping, the combination of cognitive radio channels and information-theoretic security has received little attention. The text mentions a recent study on secure communication over multiple input, single output (MISO) cognitive radio channels.
• **Collaborative Relay Beamforming in Cognitive Radio**: The paper investigates collaborative relay beamforming under secrecy constraints in cognitive radio networks. It characterizes the secrecy rate of the amplify-and-forward (AF) cognitive relay channel and formulates the beamforming optimization as a quasiconvex optimization problem.
• **Suboptimal Null Space Beamforming Schemes**: The paper proposes two suboptimal null space beamforming schemes to reduce computational complexity. These schemes involve choosing the beamforming vector to lie in the null space of the eavesdropper's channel or both the eavesdropper's and primary user's channels.

• The @xmath0-invariance of Maxwell's equations was discovered a century ago by Cunningham and Bateman.
• However, gauge freedom requires a gauge fixing condition, typically the Lorenz gauge, which breaks @xmath0-invariance.
• The purpose of the present paper is to demonstrate the benefits of maintaining @xmath0-invariance during the quantization of the Maxwell field in conformally flat spaces (CFS).
• A classical @xmath0-invariant field cannot distinguish between two CFS, so why not maintain @xmath0-invariance during quantization?
• This approach allows a free field in a CFS to behave like in flat space, and the corresponding Wightman two-point functions can be related to their Minkowskian counterparts.
• The work confirms this assertion in the special case of the Maxwell field in de Sitter space, where a new and simple two-point Wightman function was found.
• The present work extends this to general CFS and clarifies the quantum structure of the formalism.
• The six-dimensional Lorentzian space is used, and all CFS are realized as intersections of the null cone and a given surface in this space.
• The introduction of auxiliary fields and the use of the Gupta-Bleuler quantization scheme are necessary to deal with the gauge freedom of the Maxwell field.

• The parallel chip-firing game is a periodic automaton on graphs where vertices, each containing non-negative chips, fire one chip to each neighbor if possible.
• The game's rules, notation, and basic properties are defined, including the step operator, period, and transient length.
• Bitar and Goles introduced the game in 1992, and Komíners and Komíners showed that all connected graphs satisfying a certain condition have a period of 1.
• Levine proved that the complete graph has periods at most 4, but Kiwi et al. constructed a counterexample disproving Bitar's conjecture that all games have periods at most 4.
• The game is a special case of the general chip-firing game and an example of an abelian sandpile, with deep connections to number theory, algebra, and combinatorics.
• The game can simulate classical computer gates and a pile of particles that falls when too many particles stack at any point.
• The paper focuses on finding all possible periods for the complete bipartite graph and constructing positions on the complete k-partite graph with period 17 for all k.
• Lemmas and propositions are proven to limit the number of chips on each vertex, define a complement position, and characterize a period of the game on any connected graph.
• The main result is that a non-negative integer is a possible period of a position on the complete bipartite graph if and only if it belongs to certain sets.
• Future research directions include bounding periods of positions on vertex-regular graphs, determining which periods less than the bound are possible, and studying the transient length of games on certain graphs.

• The source document discusses the observation and analysis of GRB 090510, a gamma-ray burst detected by multiple spacecraft.
• The burst was initially thought to be a long GRB but was later reclassified as a short GRB due to its lack of nesting conditions.
• The document presents a new analysis of GRB 090510 using the fireshell theory, which describes the evolution of a baryon-loaded pair plasma in a gravitational collapse leading to the formation of a Kerr-Newman black hole.
• The analysis reveals three distinct episodes in the burst: the proper GRB (p-GRB), the prompt emission, and the high-energy (GeV) emission.
• The p-GRB spectrum is best fitted by a convolution of thermal spectra originating in a dyadotorus, indicating the presence of a rotating black hole.
• The GeV emission is delayed relative to the start of the GRB and is interpreted as originating from the newly formed black hole.

* The text discusses the renormalization of the Standard Model (SM) and two models with new physics: one with a real scalar triplet and another with a left-right symmetry.
* The SM has three fundamental parameters, while the other two models require a fourth input parameter due to the presence of new physics at tree level.
* The dependence of the W boson mass on the top quark mass is logarithmic in the triplet model and weakened in the left-right model, unlike the quadratic dependence in the SM.

• A log-Riemann surface is a Riemann surface with a local holomorphic diffeomorphism to the complex plane, such that the set of points added in the metric completion is discrete.
• The map extends to the metric completion as a Lipschitz map.
• The map restricted to a small punctured neighborhood of a ramification point is a covering of a punctured disc.
• The order of the ramification point is the degree of this covering.
• A log-Riemann surface of finite type has finitely many ramification points and a finitely generated fundamental group.
• It is given by a punctured compact Riemann surface and a meromorphic function with exponential singularities at the punctures.
• An exp-algebraic curve is an equivalence class of such log-Riemann surfaces.
• A topological space can be associated to an exp-algebraic curve.
• A divisor can be defined for a meromorphic function or differential with exponential singularities.

* <summary>
* The text discusses a method for solving the Anderson impurity model in a general multiorbital case using a rational interpolative formula for the self-energy.
* The method uses a set of linear equations for the coefficients in the interpolative formula, determined by a set of constraints.
* The constraints include the hartree fock value, the mean number of particles, the zero frequency value of the self-energy, the quasiparticle mass renormalization, and the positions of the hubbard bands.
* The method uses the slave boson mean field (SBMF) approach and the hubbard i approximation to determine the functional dependence of the coefficients upon doping, degeneracy, and the strength of the interaction.
* The SBFM method is found to be more accurate than the hubbard i approximation in predicting the parameters of interpolation.
* The interpolative method is compared with the quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) method, and it is found to reproduce the trends in the QMC results with a satisfactory accuracy.
* The method is computationally efficient and can be used to explore all space of parameters where neither dopings nor even degeneracy itself is kept fixed.
* The method is robust and solutions exist for all regimes of parameters.
* The method can be improved by including fluctuations beyond the mean field solution and by adjusting the width of the quasiparticle band.
* The method can be used to calculate properties of realistic solid state systems where the bandwidth and the strength of the interaction are not known at the beginning.
* </summary>

* The study focuses on the effects of inert sites on the phase transitions of the Ziff-Gulari-Barshad (ZGB) model, a lattice model for surface reactions.
* The model is modified to include a random distribution of inert sites on the catalytic surface, and the phase diagram, spinodal and transition lines, and hysteresis curves are determined using mean-field site and pair approximations, as well as Monte Carlo simulations.

• The paper discusses the hydrodynamic limit for interacting particle systems on crystal lattices.
• Crystal lattices are a generalization of classical lattice structures, with periodic global structures but inhomogeneous local structures.
• The paper constructs a scaling limit of crystal lattices using discrete harmonic maps.
• The hydrodynamic limit for exclusion processes on crystal lattices is obtained as an extension of the one on the euclidean lattice.
• The symmetric simple exclusion process is a prototype of the results, and the weakly asymmetric simple exclusion process is a perturbation of it.
• The paper proves the main theorem, which states that the density of particles is governed by a quasi-linear parabolic equation in the limit.
• The proof of the main theorem is based on the local ergodic theorem, which enables the replacement of local averages by global averages and the verification of the limit partial differential equation.
• The local ergodic theorem is formulated using local function bundles and two types of local averages.
• The proof of the local ergodic theorem is based on the one-block estimate and the two-blocks estimate.
• The paper gives examples of crystal lattices and their embeddings into the euclidean space, and discusses the relationship between geometric structures of crystal lattices and the macroscopic behaviors of particles.

• **Harmonic Maps**: Introduced by Fuller, Nash, and Sampson, harmonic maps are critical points of the energy functional between Riemannian or pseudo-Riemannian manifolds.
• **Energy Functional**: Defined using the volume measure and energy density, which involves the second fundamental form of the map.
• **Tension Field**: The trace of the second fundamental form, vanishing of which makes a map harmonic.
• **Hessian and Index**: The Hessian of a harmonic map is defined via a two-parameter variation, and its index is the dimension of the subspace where it's negative definite.
• **Stability**: A harmonic map is stable if its Morse index is zero, otherwise it's unstable.
• **Almost Para-Hermitian Manifolds**: These are manifolds with an almost para-complex structure and a compatible pseudo-Riemannian metric.
• **Para-Kähler Manifolds**: A special class of almost para-Hermitian manifolds where the fundamental 2-form is closed.
• **Almost Paracontact Manifolds**: Manifolds with an almost paracontact structure, which includes an endomorphism, a vector field, and a 1-form.
• **Para-Sasakian Manifolds**: A subclass of almost paracontact metric manifolds with specific conditions on the structure and metric.

<summary>
* The star formation rate (SFR) of galaxies is a crucial measure for understanding their growth and evolution, and unregulated SFR can lead to an overabundance of high-mass galaxies. Supermassive black holes (SMBHs) in the centers of galaxies are thought to play a role in regulating SFR through feedback processes, such as heating or removing gas from the interstellar medium (ISM).
* The authors present a large sample of 313 nearby Seyfert galaxies (Sy1 and Sy2) selected using ultra-hard X-ray observations with the Swift/Burst Alert Telescope (BAT), and they have created and analyzed Spire images for this sample to study the far-infrared (FIR) properties of these galaxies.
* The study finds that Sy2s are detected at a higher rate and have slightly higher FIR luminosities than Sy1s, suggesting that the global FIR properties of AGN are independent of orientation. The FIR luminosities are correlated with each other, but not with the 14195 keV luminosity, a proxy for the bolometric AGN luminosity. The authors speculate that the AGN is unlikely to be strongly affecting the FIR emission, but Sy1s show a very weak correlation at 250 and 350 µm.
* The spire colors of the AGN sample are similar to those of high-stellar-mass star-forming galaxies, indicating that the FIR emission of AGN host galaxies is likely produced by cold dust in the ISM heated by stellar radiation. However, six AGN have anomalous colors, and their FIR seds are dominated by synchrotron emission from a radio jet rather than thermally heated dust.
</summary>

* Myles Hollander is a statistician who has made significant contributions to the field of nonparametric statistics.
* He has written three books on the subject, including a popular introduction to statistical thinking called "The Statistical Exorcist".
* Hollander has also served as the editor of the Theory and Methods section of the Journal of the American Statistical Association (JASA) from 1994 to 1996.
* He was awarded the Noether Senior Scholar Award in 2003 for his work in nonparametric statistics.

• The fundamental group of the complement of plane curves is a topological invariant used in various applications, such as distinguishing connected components of moduli spaces of smooth projective surfaces and computing the fundamental groups of complements of hypersurfaces in projective space.
• The Zariski-Lefschetz hyperplane section theorem states that the fundamental group of the complement of a hypersurface in projective space can be computed using the fundamental group of the complement of its projection onto a generic 2-plane.
• A pair of plane curves is called a Zariski pair if they have the same combinatorics but their complements in the plane are not homeomorphic. Finding more examples of Zariski pairs is an active area of research.
• The fundamental group of the complement of the affine Ceva arrangement has no conjugation-free geometric presentation, which is the minimal arrangement with this property.
• The fundamental group of a real arrangement whose graph has a unique cycle of length 3 and has no line with more than two multiple points has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.
• The fundamental group of a real arrangement whose graph is a unique cycle of any length and has no line with more than two multiple points also has a conjugation-free geometric presentation. This result can be generalized to arrangements whose graphs are unions of disjoint cycles.

• The text discusses a model that generates non-zero complex @xmath0 and non-zero CP violation in the leptonic sector through the explicit breaking of @xmath1 symmetry.
• The model is based on the @xmath15 symmetry and gives rise to diagonal @xmath2 and @xmath24 matrices.
• The neutrino sector gives rise to the following dirac and majorana matrices, and the structure of light neutrino mass matrix can be obtained from the see-saw formula.
• The model predicts @xmath19 ( @xmath20 ) which is consistent with the chooz - palo verde experimental upper bound.
• The model also admits hierarchical masses of the three charged leptons, while the neutrino masses are quasi-degenerate or hierarchical.
• The model generates non-zero @xmath0 and possibility of non-zero CP violation has been extensively studied.
• The model predicts @xmath107 ( @xmath20 ) which is consistent with the chooz - palo verde experimental upper bound.
• The model also predicts @xmath144 ( @xmath316) and @xmath317 well below the present experimental upper bound.
• The model predicts large @xmath160 which compensates small @xmath107 effect in @xmath144 and makes it observable size.
• The model predicts the observed baryon asymmetry for a right-handed neutrino mass scale of @xmath8 gev.

• Organic molecular crystals are promising for nanoscale devices in electronics and optoelectronics.
• They are composed of an organic active part and an inorganic contact, with the interface's electronic structure crucial for device performance.
• Charge transfer between the organic and inorganic components and the energies involved need to be understood.
• Upon adsorption on a substrate, a molecule's electron addition and removal energies change from their gas phase counterparts due to image charge effects.
• A quasiparticle (qp) description is commonly used to calculate these energies, but it has limitations, especially for molecules.
• Density functional theory (DFT) can be used, but local and semi-local approximations perform poorly for molecular energies.
• Hybrid functionals, self-interaction corrections, and range-separated functionals improve results but still have limitations.
• The formation of the image charge is a non-local phenomenon, challenging for most functionals.
• The GW approximation can capture energy levels renormalization but is computationally demanding.
• Constrained density functional theory (CDFT) is a resource-efficient alternative for calculating charge transfer energies in organic-inorganic interfaces.

* The study investigates critical casimir forces (CCFs) between two spherical colloids near a planar substrate, focusing on the influence of many-body effects.
* The colloids have different boundary conditions (BCs) and are positioned at varying distances from each other and the substrate.
* The study finds that many-body effects can significantly alter the CCFs, leading to changes in the direction and magnitude of the forces compared to pairwise interactions.

<summary>
* Molecular hydrogen (H2) is abundant in the universe and plays a crucial role in the chemistry of the interstellar medium (ISM).
* Its formation is governed by the transformation of atomic diffuse clouds into molecular clouds, with dust grains being the favored habitat for H2 formation.
* The sticking of hydrogen atoms (H) onto dust surfaces is an important mechanism for H2 formation and gas cooling in the ISM.
* Previous studies have shown that H atoms can be weakly (physisorbed) or strongly (chemisorbed) bound to dust surfaces, with both states being relevant for H2 formation.
* In the ISM, dust grains are mainly carbonaceous or silicate particles, with a significant portion of the available surface area being in the form of very small grains or polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).
* PAHs are predicted to have characteristics similar to graphite surfaces, with barrierless or reduced barrier adsorption of H atoms in pairs.
* However, the inefficient sticking of H atoms in monomers constitutes an important obstacle to enter the catalytic regime for H2 formation on graphitic/PAH surfaces.
* The hydrogenation on the PAH edges has been identified as an important route to form H2 in the ISM, with neutral PAHs being efficient catalysts for H2 formation when highly hydrogenated.
</summary>

<summary>
* Atomic clocks are passive and require an active oscillator for ticking, which needs to be steered towards an aiming point.
* The resonance exhibited by the atom or atoms of the clock varies with the details of the clock's construction and operation, and shifts depending on the intensity of the radiation of the atoms by the oscillator.
* The second as a measurement unit in the international system of units (SI) is defined by the resonance that would be found at absolute zero temperature, implying zero radiation.
* For a clock using cesium 133 atoms, this imagined resonance is declared by the general conference of weights and measures to be 9,192,631,770 Hz.
* The wave function incorporated into the operation of an atomic clock can never be unconditionally known, and no wave function can be unconditionally known, even probabilities of future evidence cannot be unconditionally foreseen.
* Clocks that generate universal coordinated time (UTC) are steered towards aiming points that depend not only on a chosen wave function but also on an hypothesized metric tensor field of a curved spacetime.
* Guesses enter the operations of clocks through the computational machinery that steers them, taking incoming data, updating records that determine an aiming point, and involving the writing and reading of records.
* The wider physical world shows up in an open machine as both unforeseeable messages from external devices and commands to external devices.
* The acquisition of logical synchrony in digital communications involves an unforeseeable waiting time, like the time for a coin on edge to fall one way or the other.
</summary>

• **IEEE 802.15.4 Standard Overview**:
  - Designed for low power, low data rate wireless personal area networks (WPANs).
  - Operates in 2.4 GHz, 915 MHz, and 868 MHz frequency bands.
  - Supports star and peer-to-peer topologies, with beacon-enabled and non-beacon-enabled modes.

• **Non-Beacon Enabled Mode**:
  - Uses unslotted CSMA/CA for channel access.
  - Two main variables: backoff exponent (BE) and number of backoffs (NB).
  - CSMA/CA algorithm: random backoff, clear channel assessment, busy channel, idle channel.

• **Collision Avoidance**:
  - CSMA/CA reduces collision probability compared to CSMA.
  - RTS/CTS exchange technique used for improved performance.
  - Combined with DSSS and FHSS for higher throughput in real-time applications.

• **Performance Metrics**:
  - Load: Total bits submitted to 802.15.4 MAC by higher layers.
  - Throughput: Total bits forwarded from 802.15.4 MAC to higher layers.
  - Delay: End-to-end delay of packets received by 802.15.4 MACs.
  - End-to-end delay: Total delay between packet creation and reception.

• **Simulation Parameters**:
  - 10 sensor nodes, coordinator collecting data.
  - Data rates: 20, 40, 250 kbps.
  - Ack and non-ack cases considered.
  - OPNET Modeler used for simulations.

• **Performance Analysis at 20 kbps**:
  - Load remains constant, throughput and delay increase with load.
  - Delay occurs due to packet collisions and channel access failures.
  - Ack case shows higher delay and lower throughput due to collisions.

• **Performance Analysis at 40 kbps**:
  - Lower delay and higher throughput compared to 20 kbps.
  - Increase in data rate reduces delay and increases throughput.
  - Ack case shows lower delay and higher throughput due to less collisions.

• **Performance Analysis at 250 kbps**:
  - Negligible delay, throughput and load show same behavior.
  - Less collision probability and channel access failures.
  - Ack and non-ack cases perform similarly due to high data rate.

• **Future Research**:
  - Investigate performance

<summary>
* **MOPED Algorithm**: The Multiple Optimised Parameter Estimation and Data Compression (MOPED) algorithm is used to compress data and speed up likelihood function evaluations in astronomical data analysis. It maintains the Fisher matrix of the likelihood at a chosen point, but may struggle with multimodal and degenerate distributions.
* **Speed Benefits**: When MOPED accurately represents the likelihood function, it provides significant speed improvements, with runtime reductions of up to two orders of magnitude demonstrated in previous studies.
* **Limitations**: MOPED may not accurately portray the true likelihood function in certain scenarios, such as when the noise covariance matrix is dependent on the model parameters. This can lead to incorrect results in parameter estimation.
* **Solutions and Further Research**: To address these limitations, the authors suggest using multiple fiducial models to create multiple sets of weighting vectors and averaging the log-likelihood across these choices. Further research is needed to fully understand and mitigate the potential issues with MOPED.
</summary>

<summary>
* The cosmological constant problem (CCP) is a major puzzle in particle physics, consisting of three main pieces: the vacuum energy density can be the cosmological constant, it can receive large radiative corrections, and its experimental value is much smaller than theoretical estimates.
* The vacuum energy density can have various sources, such as zero-point energy of particles, energy from phase transitions like the Higgs mechanism, and chiral symmetry breaking due to quark condensations.
* The observed tiny vacuum energy density compared to theoretical estimates is a big riddle, and the identity of dark energy density is a big mystery.
* In the absence of gravity, the vacuum energy from matters is not directly observed, but in the presence of gravity, it may affect the motion of planets, threatening the stability of the solar system.
* It is assumed that the classical gravitational field does not feel a large portion of the vacuum energy, but it couples to every process containing radiative corrections.
* A conjecture is made that a dominant part of dark energy can originate from gravitational corrections of vacuum energy around the terascale, under certain assumptions about the coupling of gravitons and the nature of external gravitons.
</summary>

* The paper presents a spectroscopic technique called two-color modulation transfer spectroscopy for studying atomic properties in higher excited states.
* The method uses two lasers, one for pumping and one for probing, with one of them modulated to create sidebands.
* The absorption of the pump laser is monitored as a function of probe laser detuning, generating sub-Doppler peaks with sidebands.
* The technique overcomes experimental challenges of low signal-to-noise ratio and lack of detectors at desired wavelengths.

<summary>
* The physics potential of forward proton tagging at the LHC has attracted significant attention.
* Central exclusive production (CEP) process, where protons remain intact and the central system is separated by a large rapidity gap, is a main focus.
* Observation of any particle in the CEP channel provides a direct observation of its quantum numbers.
* By detecting the outgoing protons and measuring their energy loss accurately, the mass of the centrally produced particle can be measured regardless of its decay products.
* The FP420 collaboration has proposed to install detectors in the region 420 m from the interaction points, allowing the detection of central systems in the approximate mass range 70-140 GeV.
* Proposals also exist to upgrade the capabilities of ATLAS and CMS to detect protons in the 220 m region, extending the accessible mass range.
* The CEP process is shown schematically in Figure [centralexclusive].
* The dominant decay channel of the Higgs boson in the mass region of interest is to bb, which is very difficult to observe in conventional Higgs searches at the LHC due to the large QCD background.
* </summary>

* The text discusses the zero-field hall effect in chiral @xmath0-wave superconductors (SCs) near the Kosterlitz-Thouless (KT) transition.
* The hall effect arises from vortex dynamics, specifically the unbinding of vortex-antivortex pairs.
* The hall conductivity is nonzero due to the asymmetric response of opposite vortices to the driving field.
* The convective term in the Fokker-Planck equation, unique to chiral @xmath0-wave SCs, is essential for this asymmetry.
* The sign change in the hall conductivity is related to the KT transition.
* The power dissipation also diverges in the static limit in the low temperature phase.
* The free vortex contribution to the total conductivity tensor can be distinguished from the bound pair contribution.
* The bound pair contribution to the hall conductivity is influenced by the dip-recouping shape of the transverse response function.

<summary>
* The measurement of rotation curves (RCs) of disk galaxies is a powerful tool to investigate the nature of dark matter (DM), including its content relative to baryonic components and their distributions. Dwarf galaxies are good candidates for this purpose as their kinematics are generally dominated by the dark component, down to small galactocentric radii.
* The Orion dwarf galaxy is examined in this study due to its extended disk, providing an important test of the paradigm that the kinematics of dwarf galaxies point towards a cored profile for the DM halo.
* The Orion dwarf's RC is derived from 21-cm surface brightness and kinematics data, which shows a large mass discrepancy at all radii and has a well-modeled baryonic component distribution. The distance to the galaxy is estimated to be 5.4±1.0 Mpc.
* The DM content of the Orion dwarf is modeled using a cored/cusped halo framework, with the RC in the stellar disk being modeled using an exponential thin disk with a scale length of 1.33 kpc. The DM halo is modeled using either an NFW profile or the cored profile of the Halo Universal Rotation Curve (URCH).
</summary>

<summary>
* The trihydrogen dication (H3+) is a simple Coulomb system that has been studied for its stability.
* Conroy investigated its potential energy surfaces in the 1960s and 1970s, concluding it's not stable.
* Berkowitz and Stocker searched for H3+ through charge stripping experiments but found no evidence of its stability.
* Later, Shoucri and Darling, and Hernandez and Carb revisited the question using different methods, but no bound state was found.
* Ackermann et al. used the finite element method and excluded the possibility of stable H3+ in the electronic ground state.
* The present study aims to address the question of H3+ stability using two variational methods.
* The first method uses a specialized trial function with physically relevant basis functions.
* The second method uses standard Gaussian trial functions as implemented in quantum chemistry packages like Molpro.
* Both methods lead to accurate quantitative results for total energy versus the size of the triangle.
* The specialized variational method uses a trial function with six basis functions, each describing different physical characteristics of the system.
* The standard variational method uses Gaussian basis functions centered at atoms, with coefficients determined variationally.
* The calculations were performed using the Hartree-Fock code in the Molpro suite with correlation consistent cc-pV6Z and modified mcc-pV7Z basis sets.
* The cc-pV6Z basis set contains 91 contracted Gaussians per atom, while the mcc-pV7Z basis includes 140 functions.
* Calculations were carried out for a range of equilateral triangular configurations using D3h symmetry.
* The total number of contracted Gaussians of this symmetry is 168 for the cc-pV6Z basis set and 255 for the mcc-pV7Z basis set.
* The specialized variational method's results indicate no minimum or non-adiabatic irregularities for finite interproton distances.
* Therefore, the molecular ion H3+ does not exist in an equilateral triangular configuration in the Born-Oppenheimer approximation.
* The authors express gratitude to J.C. López Vieyra for valuable comments and Universite Libre de Bruxelles for hospitality.
* The work was supported by Fenomec and PAPIIT grant IN121106.
</summary>

• The Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) has revealed complex relationships between galaxy properties and their environments.
• Galaxy clustering is a function of both star formation history (color and luminosity) and luminosity.
• For red galaxies, clustering is a non-monotonic function of luminosity, peaking at both high and low luminosities.
• Galaxy environment is independent of surface brightness and concentration at fixed color and luminosity.
• The study investigates the scale dependence of these relationships to test assumptions of the "halo model" of galaxy formation.

<summary>
* Transverse spin fluctuations are gapless, low-energy excitations in magnetic systems with continuous spin-rotational symmetry.
* They play a crucial role in various macroscopic properties, such as long-range order, order parameter magnitude, Nèel temperature, and spin correlations.
* In the antiferromagnetic ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model, transverse spin fluctuations significantly reduce the zero-temperature antiferromagnetic order parameter in two dimensions.
* The Nèel temperature in three dimensions is also reduced due to spin fluctuations.
* Spin fluctuations are enhanced by spin vacancies in the quantum antiferromagnet, leading to a critical vacancy concentration where the antiferromagnetic order parameter vanishes.
* Low-concentration impurities in the Hubbard model suppress quantum spin fluctuations, enhancing magnetic order.
* The method described in the paper evaluates transverse spin correlations and quantum spin-fluctuation corrections about the Hartree-Fock level broken-symmetry state, using magnon mode energies and spectral functions obtained in the random phase approximation (RPA).
* The method is applicable in the whole interaction strength range and is illustrated with three applications involving the antiferromagnetic ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model.
</summary>

<summary>
* The study of nonequilibrium dynamics in quantum field theory has gained significant attention, particularly in cosmology, with inflation being the most successful known mechanism for explaining the large-scale homogeneity and isotropy of the universe.
* Inflation has led to the development of multi-field models, where the inflaton is coupled to another dynamical field during inflation, leading to a variety of features unavailable in single-field scenarios.
* The subsequent phase of energy transfer between the inflaton and other degrees of freedom leading to the standard picture of big bang cosmology has been the subject of intense study, with the inflaton decaying through perturbative processes and non-perturbative parametric amplification.
* Hybrid inflation and reheating models share an important common thread, involving the coupling of two or more dynamical, interacting scalar fields, with an important aspect being the possibility of mixing between the fields.
* The study of renormalization of time evolution equations in single field models was understood several years ago, with Cooper and Mottola showing that it is possible to find a renormalization procedure leading to counter terms independent of time and initial conditions of the mean field.
</summary>

<summary>
* The existence of dark matter (dm) is established, and its thermal relic abundance has been determined by the WMAP experiment.
* The weakly interacting massive particle (wimp) is a promising candidate for dm, and the Higgs triplet model (htm) is a simple way to generate tiny neutrino masses.
* In the htm, majorana masses for neutrinos are generated via a yukawa interaction with a nonzero vacuum expectation value (vev) of an SU(2) triplet scalar field.
* The scalar potential in the htm can be written as a sum of terms involving the Higgs doublet field, the triplet field, and their interactions.
* The htm does not contain a dark matter candidate by itself, but it can be extended to include one.
* The authors present a model that extends the htm by introducing a singlet scalar field with a nonzero vev, which breaks lepton number conservation and generates the @x14 parameter at the one-loop level.
* The model contains a dark matter candidate that is a linear combination of two @x1-odd scalars, one of which is a real singlet and the other is a doublet.
* The model predicts a small @x14 parameter, which is generated at the one-loop level, and a large mass scale @x92, which is not small.
</summary>

• Quantum key distribution (QKD) enables secure communication, but requires a quantum-enabled network.
• This network must accommodate quantum properties and contain novel components like quantum memories and repeaters.
• No technology is perfect, and quantum technologies offer practical challenges, but classical post-processing can deal with imperfections.
• A minimal quantum requirement for devices is that they do not act as measure and prepare channels, which destroy quantum correlations.
• To quantify a channel's quantum behavior, we can send one subsystem of an entangled state through the channel and examine the output.
• In a prepare and measure (PM) scenario, we can use homodyne measurements to estimate important parameters and make quantitative statements about the optical device.
• Our main goal is to estimate the amount of effective entanglement observable in an optical system after transmission through an optical channel.

<summary>
* The study of dipole moments of elementary particles has provided valuable information on subatomic physics.
* The magnetic moment of a charged particle with spin 1/2 is given by the formula μ = g * (e * ħ / 2m), where g is the gyromagnetic ratio and m is the mass of the particle.
* The Dirac equation tells us that for spin-1/2 particles, g = 2, and the anomaly arises from radiative corrections.
* For baryons, the internal quark structure gives them large anomalies.
* The electron anomaly is now measured to a relative precision of about four parts in a billion, and the muon anomaly is measured to 0.5 parts per million.
* The muon anomaly is sensitive to physics at the 100 GeV scale.
* The standard model value of the muon anomaly has measurable contributions from qed loops, hadronic loops, and weak loops.
* A discrepancy between the experimental value and the standard model prediction would signify the presence of new physics.
* The CERN experiment observed the contribution of hadronic vacuum polarization at the 8 standard deviation level.
* The muon (g-2) experiment at Brookhaven National Laboratory aims to measure the muon anomaly with a precision of 0.14 ppm.
* The muon electric dipole moment (EDM) is predicted to be measurable in some supersymmetric models.
* A new experiment to search for a permanent EDM of the muon with a design sensitivity of 10^-24 e·cm is being planned for J-PARC.
* The muon EDM would cause a steady build-up of the spin out of the plane with time, which can be detected using asymmetry in the decay positrons.
* The figure of merit for statistics in the muon EDM experiment is the number of muons times the polarization.
* Measurements of the muon and electron anomalies played an important role in our understanding of subatomic physics in the 20th century.
* The search for EDMs will continue, and if one is observed, it would provide strong motivation for further searches in other systems.
* If supersymmetry is the extension to the standard model, there will be susy enhancements to the muon anomaly, muon EDM, and lepton flavor violating muon decays.
* Precision experiments, such as EDM searches and searches for lepton flavor violation, will continue to be a topic of great importance in the

• The paper presents a new optomechanical system design consisting of a microdisk resonator coupled to a waveguide, enabling the study of reactive effects in optomechanical coupling.
• The origin of reactive coupling lies in the mechanical motion dependence of the extrinsic losses of the disk resonator and phase-dependent gradient forces.
• The system is pumped with a strong field at frequency ω₀ and probed with a weak field at frequency ω₁, with the waveguide moving along the z-direction under optical force.
• The Hamiltonian of the system is given, including terms for the energy of the cavity field, waveguide, and interactions between them and the incident fields.
• The time evolutions of the expectation values of the system operators are solved, and the expectation value of the output fields is calculated, revealing reactive-coupling-induced normal mode splitting.

• The article explores the dynamics of transverse magnetization transport in a one-dimensional quantum Ising chain.
• The system is initially prepared in a nonequilibrium state with inhomogeneity in transverse magnetization.
• The evolution of the system is studied in the presence of a homogeneous and constant external transverse field.
• The magnetization does not become homogeneous even after infinite time, due to the presence of odd-occupation states.
• The magnetization exhibits oscillatory behavior with a power-law decay in the envelope, independent of the field strength.
• The frequency of oscillation shows a non-analytic behavior at the critical point of the quantum phase transition.
• The final magnetization at each site also exhibits different behavior in the ordered and disordered phases.
• The initial configuration contains several parameters, and the observed dynamics is valid for arbitrary values of these parameters.

• The text discusses the behavior of QCD at finite baryon density, focusing on compact stars and conditions near the core of collapsing stars.
• The existence of a color superconducting phase in dense quark matter is mentioned.
• The text reviews chromomagnetic instabilities in the gapless 2sc and g2sc phases.
• The instability of off-diagonal gluons appears in the whole region of gapless 2sc phases and even in some gapped 2sc phases.
• The behavior of the diagonal 8th gluon's meissner mass square is different from that of off-diagonal gluons.
• The text also discusses the instability of a neutral baryon current in the g2sc phase.
• The paramagnetic response to an external vector current suggests the spontaneous generation of a vector current in the system.
• The text mentions the existence of a narrow unstable loff (us-loff) window where not only off-diagonal gluons but also the diagonal 8th gluon can exhibit magnetic instability.

<summary>
* The debate about the properties of the melting phase transition of two-dimensional systems has not been resolved, with different studies reporting first, second, or Kosterlitz-Thouless-Halperin-Nelson-Young (KTHNY) like transitions.
* The authors conducted microcanonical molecular dynamics simulations of a two-dimensional Yukawa system to investigate the equilibration of the system and found that the velocity distribution function, configurational temperature, and long-range correlations relax at different time scales, with the latter being the slowest and dependent on system size.
</summary>

• The Kepler mission discovered over 4100 planetary candidates in 3200 systems.
• Small planets are nearly ubiquitous, with some of the most common being super-Earths to mini-Neptunes.
• The transition from rocky to non-rocky planets occurs near a radius of 4 R⊕ and is very sharp.
• Understanding the radii of these planets is crucial for comprehending their structures and occurrence rates.
• The Kepler pipeline treats each candidate host star as single, but some stars may have companions.
• Undetected companions can change observed transit depths and derived planetary radii.
• Assuming all stars are single can introduce systematic uncertainties in planetary radii and occurrence rates.
• The presence of a stellar companion does not necessarily invalidate a planetary candidate but changes transit depths.
• The authors present probabilistic uncertainties of planetary radii based on expected stellar multiplicity rates and companion sizes.
• Radial velocity and high-resolution imaging vetting can significantly reduce the underestimation of planetary radii.

<summary>
* The range of HI column densities in nearby galaxy observations is similar to that of damped Lyα systems (DLAs).
* Mapping HI gas in DLAs using 21-cm emission is challenging due to the line's weakness and current technology limitations.
* DLAs are typically identified through absorption in background quasar spectra, which is not distance-dependent.
* There are few known DLAs with 21-cm emission within the reach of current radio telescopes.
* Most DLA studies rely on optical wavelengths, with limited success in directly imaging host galaxies.
* There are now around 100 DLA galaxies known, spanning a wide range in properties.
* A statistical study using 21-cm emission line surveys can link DLA properties to local universe knowledge.
* The WHISP sample of local galaxies was used to calculate the column density distribution function of HI.
* The study found mild evolution in the HI intersection cross-section from redshift 2 to the present.
* The local galaxy population can explain the incidence rate and metallicities of DLAs, their host galaxy luminosities, and impact parameters.
</summary>

• The vast majority of stars are thought to form in star clusters, with only a modest percentage of gas turned into stars initially.
• During the collapse and fragmentation of a giant molecular cloud into a star cluster, the gas is later expelled due to stellar winds and supernovae explosions.
• This rapid gas loss leaves the cluster out of equilibrium, causing it to undergo violent relaxation and attempt to return to virial equilibrium.
• The authors present observations of three young massive clusters (M82-F, NGC 1569-A, and NGC 1705-1) using Hubble Space Telescope data.
• They find that all three clusters display an excess of light at large radii, suggesting that they are not in dynamical equilibrium.
• The authors model the clusters using N-body simulations, representing the gas as an external potential removed on a certain timescale.
• They conclude that the observations are best explained by rapid gas removal, with effective star formation efficiencies of around 40-50%.

• The text discusses the interplay between quantum fluctuation, tunneling, and decoherence in a one-dimensional double-well system driven by a polychromatic external field.
• The system's Hamiltonian is time-dependent, with the number of frequency components (n) and perturbation strength (a) as key parameters.
• The initial state is a Gaussian wavepacket localized in the right well, with a recurrence time of approximately 100 in the unperturbed case.
• The transition probability (P) between wells is calculated, with coherent and irregular motions observed depending on the parameters.
• A degree of coherence (C) is defined to quantify the difference between coherent and incoherent motions.
• The motion is classified into coherent, irregular, and transitional cases based on the degree of coherence.
• The critical value of the perturbation strength (a_c) that divides regular and irregular motions depends on the number of frequency components (n).
• The tunneling period decreases monotonically with increasing perturbation strength in the coherent motion regime.
• The uncertainty product (ΔxΔp) is used as a measure of quantum fluctuation, with different behaviors observed in coherent and irregular motions.
• The polychromatically perturbed system approaches the behavior of a stochastically perturbed system as the number of frequency components increases.

* The text discusses a stochastic formulation of open quantum systems, starting from a set of coupled stochastic differential equations and averaging over noise realizations to obtain the von Neumann equation.
* The stochastic formalism is then used to derive a stochastic Liouville equation (SLE) for the reduced density matrix, which can be solved using various numerical methods.

<summary>
* The glass transition, a sharp increase in relaxation times, is still an unresolved problem in statistical physics.
* The Kauzmann temperature is proposed as the ideal glass transition point, where only one minimum-energy basin is accessible.
* Experimental data and simulations of polydisperse hard-core disks challenge the existence of a thermodynamic transition.
* Mode coupling theory (MCT) predicts a transition from a high-temperature liquid to a low-temperature arrested state at a critical temperature.
* The full MCT shows no sharp transition, but all structural correlations decay in a final process.
* The nonergodicity parameters, solutions of the MCT equations at long times, characterize the long-time behavior of the intermediate scattering function.
* The authors investigate a Ni-Zr glass-forming system using molecular dynamics simulations and analyze the nonergodicity parameters, the f-function, and diffusion coefficients.
* The critical temperature (T_c) estimated from the nonergodicity parameters is 1005 K, while estimates from the f-function and diffusion coefficients are around 950 K.
* The authors consider the discrepancy between the estimates from the ergodic and nonergodic sides as significant but smaller than previously observed in a Lennard-Jones system.
</summary>

• **Source Document**: The text discusses a statistical method for analyzing longitudinal dyadic data with nonignorable dropouts, using a selection model approach.
• **Motivation**: The method is motivated by a study on breast cancer patients and their spouses, focusing on depression and its interdependence within dyads.
• **Method Overview**: The proposed method models each subject's longitudinal measurement process using a transition model, including both patient and spouse characteristics as covariates. It accounts for within-dyad correlation using dyad-specific random effects.
• **Dropout Model**: To handle nonignorable dropouts, the method employs a discrete time survival model to link the dropout process with the longitudinal measurement process.
• **Data Augmentation**: The method uses a data augmentation approach to address the missing data problem caused by dropout and interdependence within dyads.
• **Simulation Studies**: The method's performance is evaluated through two simulation studies, showing consistent estimates with correct coverage rates.
• **Application to Breast Cancer Data**: The method is applied to the breast cancer data, identifying more "partner" effects than methods that ignore missing data, providing extra insights into dyad interdependence.

<summary>
* Quantum electrodynamics predicts that two neutral metallic plates in vacuum attract each other due to zero-point energy fluctuations.
* Casimir predicted this force in 1948, and Lifshitz, Dzyaloshinskii, and Pitaevskii generalized the theory to isotropic dielectrics.
* The force between two plates with arbitrary dielectric functions can be derived using an analytical formula.
* At short distances, the force is non-retarded and reduces to the van der Waals force, while at larger separations, retardation effects become important.
* The sign of the force depends on the dielectric properties of the interacting materials and the medium in which they are immersed.
* Two plates made of the same material always attract, while slabs of different materials may repel each other in certain liquids.
* Parsegian and Weiss derived an equation for the non-retarded van der Waals interaction energy between two dielectrically anisotropic plates.
* A torque develops between two parallel birefringent slabs, causing them to rotate towards alignment.
* The authors calculated the magnitude of the torque for specific materials and proposed an experimental validation using a quartz or calcite disk and a barium titanate plate in vacuum or ethanol.
</summary>

• The study explores topologically biased random walks (TBRWs) on graphs, focusing on their use in community detection.
• The paper introduces mathematical tools to analyze TBRWs, including perturbation methods and parametric equations of motion, and applies them to study spectral gaps and community finding.

• **System Architecture**: The system consists of phagocytes (special p2p hosts) managing groups of p2p hosts, with phagocytes also connected to each other.
• **Internal Defense**: Phagocytes monitor managed hosts' behavior, detect worms, isolate infected hosts, propagate alerts, and distribute software patches.
• **External Protection**: Phagocytes filter external requests, prevent p2p traffic leakage, and use an adaptive computational puzzle scheme to control access to the p2p overlay.
• **Evaluation**: Experiments show that phagocytes effectively defend against internal attacks, with performance improving with more immune managed hosts and phagocytes.
• **Comparison**: Unlike previous defense mechanisms focusing only on internal defense, this system provides holistic immunity against both internal and external active p2p worm attacks.

• **Debris Disk Systems**: Provide insights into the transition between early star and planet formation and the mature stage of stellar systems like our solar system.
• **Observation of Dust**: Infrared luminosity from dust collisions in debris disks is typically much higher than in our solar system's asteroid and Kuiper belts.
• **Gas Phase Absorption**: Researchers have been looking for gas phase absorption in debris disks, with only a few edge-on systems showing this feature, like HD 32297.
• **HD 32297**: An edge-on debris disk system around a main-sequence star, making it an ideal target for gas phase absorption measurements.
• **Observations**: High-resolution optical spectra of the Na I D doublet were obtained for HD 32297 and nearby stars to reconstruct the interstellar medium (ISM) absorption profile.
• **Results**: Two absorption components were detected toward HD 32297, with one likely caused by circumstellar material and the other by interstellar material from the local bubble's boundary.
• **Variability**: Some indication of temporal variability was detected over several epochs, with redshifted circumstellar absorption becoming stronger and more distinct.
• **Comparison**: The measured circumstellar feature toward HD 32297 is the strongest detected around a nearby main-sequence debris disk, with a gas mass estimate of ~40.3 M⊕ if assuming similar morphology and abundances as HD 1007.

* Gravity is a universal force affecting all objects with energy, though its effects are often too weak to measure due to the smallness of Newton's constant.
* Various theories of quantum gravity and black hole physics predict the existence of a minimum measurable length, which can be understood through the breakdown of the Heisenberg uncertainty principle at high energies.

* The paper presents a method to compute couplings in conformal field theories (CFTs) by deforming the theory with a marginal or irrelevant operator.
* The method is based on the renormalization of operators in the deformed theory and the computation of the anomalous dimension matrix.
* The paper focuses on the case of planar N=4 supersymmetric Yang-Mills (SYM) theory, both at weak and strong coupling.
* The authors show that the couplings in the 3-point function of the lagrangian with any two operators of the theory can be computed using integrability techniques.
* The paper also presents a new method to compute 3-point correlation functions of SYM at strong coupling using the AdS/CFT duality.
* The method involves including two insertions of an operator dual to a heavy string state and one extra chiral operator.
* The paper checks the method by computing the 3-point function of the dilaton field with two heavy string states, and finding agreement with the expected result from renormalization group arguments.
* The paper also discusses open problems and future directions, such as extending the method to other deformations and chiral operators, and computing the area of the string worldsheet minimal surface in the case of three large operators.
* The authors acknowledge helpful discussions with Joo Penedones and Pedro Vieira, and funding from Nordita, FCT, and CERN.

• The paper presents a relativistic embedding scheme for solving the Dirac equation in a limited region (i) of a larger system (i@xmath102ii), replacing region ii with an additional term in the Hamiltonian acting on the surface separating i and ii.
• The scheme uses a trial function with a continuous large component and a discontinuous small component across the surface, ensuring solutions are continuous in both components only when the embedding potential is evaluated at the same energy as the Dirac equation.

<summary>
* The analysis of dynamic processes in complex networks is a major research area with applications in social, biological, and technological systems.
* The spread of information, evolution of epidemics, and cascading failures in networks are relevant examples of these processes.
* Most modeling and analysis techniques are tailored to static networks, but real-world networks evolve over time.
* The interplay between the dynamics on and of networks is an important research direction.
* The authors study an adaptive susceptible-infected-susceptible (ASIS) model with heterogeneous node and edge dynamics over arbitrary networks.
* They derive a lower bound on the epidemic threshold and propose an efficient algorithm for optimally tuning adaptation rates.
* Numerical simulations confirm the tightness of the lower bound and compare optimal adaptation rates with centrality measures.
</summary>

* **Experimental Setup and Results:**
	+ Two dielectric microwave resonators of circular shape and different thickness were used.
	+ The prevalent modes observed were whispering gallery modes (WGMs), and the pillars supporting the resonators did not perturb them significantly.
	+ The frequency spectrum of each resonator consisted of series of roughly equidistant resonances, with the associated modes labeled by their polarization and quantum numbers.
* **Theoretical Analysis and Comparison:**
	+ The open dielectric resonators were described by the vectorial Helmholtz equation with outgoing-wave boundary conditions.
	+ The density of states (DOS) was separated into a smooth, average part and a fluctuating part, with the latter related to the periodic orbits (POS) of the corresponding classical system.
	+ The experimental length spectra were compared to the semiclassical trace formula for 2D dielectric resonators, combined with the 2D approximation of the Helmholtz equation using an effective index of refraction (n0 model).

<summary>
* **Source Document**: The document discusses the merger of two neutron stars, two black holes, or a black hole and a neutron star as significant sources of gravitational waves (GW). The coalescence of double neutron stars (DNS) is of particular interest due to the large amount of energy released in the last seconds of their inspiral trajectory, with frequencies up to 1.4 - 1.6 kHz, covered by most ground-based laser interferometers.
* **DNS Coalescence Rate**: The document revisits the question of the DNS coalescence rate, taking into account the galactic star formation history derived directly from observations and including the contribution of elliptical galaxies. Based on these results, the document predicts a detection rate of one event every 125 and 148 years by initial LIGO and Virgo respectively, and up to 6 detections per year in their advanced configurations.
* **Gravitational Wave Background**: The document also estimates the gravitational wave background spectrum produced by these coalescences. Using the DNS merging rate estimated in their precedent study, they performed numerical simulations based on Monte Carlo methods to determine the critical redshift beyond which the duty cycle condition required to have a continuous background is satisfied. The signal frequency is in the range 10 - 1500 Hz, covered by ground-based interferometers.
</summary>

<summary>
* The universe is currently in an accelerating phase, as evidenced by type Ia supernovae, cosmic microwave background radiation, and large-scale structure observations.
* This acceleration is attributed to a form of dark energy, characterized by a negative pressure, which eventually dominates over cold dark matter and drives the universe's expansion.
* The simplest candidate for dark energy is the cosmological constant, but it faces challenges such as the small observed value compared to expected quantum field theory predictions and the age problem in the Lambda-CDM paradigm.
* Alternative dark energy models, such as quintessence, phantom, k-essence, tachyon, quintom, chaplygin gas, generalized chaplygin gas, holographic dark energy, new agegraphic dark energy, and Ricci dark energy, have been proposed to address these issues.
* Additionally, modifications to the gravitational sector, such as f(R) gravity, gravity with higher curvature invariants, and teleparallel gravity, have been explored to explain the universe's acceleration and phantom crossing.
</summary>

* The text discusses a bidirectional relay network with half-duplex nodes and fading links.
* The goal is to maximize the average sum rate of both users by jointly optimizing transmission mode selection and power allocation.
* The network has six possible transmission modes, and the optimal mode selection policy is derived using Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions.
* The optimal power allocation for each mode is also derived using the KKT conditions.
* The optimal mode selection policy selects only four out of the six possible modes.
* The optimal power allocation improves the sum rate, especially when the total power budget is low.
* The proposed protocol outperforms existing protocols in terms of average sum rate.
* The advantages of buffering come at the expense of increased end-to-end delay.
* The delay analysis of the proposed protocol is beyond the scope of the current work.

• The acoustic oscillations in the matter power spectrum at recombination serve as a standard ruler for cosmological measurements.
• The length scale of this ruler can be accurately calculated using CMB anisotropy measurements.
• The interpretation of low-redshift acoustic oscillations is robust, even if CMB measurements are affected by new, undetected physics.
• The baryon-to-photon ratio and the epoch of matter-radiation equality, which are robustly measured in the CMB, are crucial for this robustness.
• The actual densities of matter and radiation drop out of the calculation, only their ratio matters.
• The sound horizon, which depends on the baryon-to-photon ratio and the redshift of equality, is the key quantity.
• Even if the physical matter density is misinterpreted from the CMB, inferences for dark energy from combined CMB and low-redshift survey data remain unchanged.

• The text discusses the question of neutrino masses and oscillations, with a focus on a specific ansatz for the neutrino mass matrix.
• The ansatz is motivated by an SO(10) grand unified model and is intended to be a possible gateway to a more fundamental theory beyond the standard model.
• The authors investigate the consequences of this ansatz and combine it with experimental results on neutrino oscillations to learn more about the neutrino mass matrix.
• They consider both the case where the neutrino mass matrix is real and hermitian, and the case where it is complex.
• The text also discusses the possibility of neutrinoless double beta decay and its implications for the neutrino mass matrix.

<summary>
* The spread of infectious diseases is influenced by the contact pattern among individuals, modeled using a contact rate function or network analysis methods.
* Scale-free networks, with a power-law degree distribution, are common in real-world networks, including human sexual contact networks, and can affect disease propagation.
* Previous studies have explored disease dissemination in scale-free networks, highlighting their heterogeneity and potential impact on acute and chronic diseases.
* The authors generated scale-free networks using the Barabási-Albert (BA) algorithm and other methods, comparing their structural properties and epidemic dynamics.
* They simulated the spread of acute and chronic diseases using SI (Susceptible-Infected) and SIS (Susceptible-Infected-Susceptible) models on these networks.
* Results showed that disease prevalence depends on network structure, with decentralized networks (e.g., MB) having lower prevalence, and directed networks showing unique dynamics.
* The study suggests that preventing infectious contacts can help control diseases, and network analysis can provide insights into disease spread and prevention.
</summary>

* The Levi-Civita (LC) spacetime, with constants @xmath3 and @xmath0, presents challenges in interpretation, particularly for @xmath0. For small @xmath0, it describes an infinite line mass, while for @xmath1, it's flat and has no circular timelike geodesics. The Kretschmann scalar decreases with increasing @xmath0, vanishing at @xmath12, suggesting flat space. However, the spacetime admits an extra Killing vector for @xmath14, implying plane symmetry. The question remains: what does LC represent for @xmath0 outside the range (0, @xmath10)?
* Interior solutions matching to LC exist with @xmath16, and the absence of circular test particle orbits may be due to velocities exceeding the speed of light. Bonnor proposes interpreting LC as a cylinder whose radius increases with @xmath0, becoming a plane at @xmath1. However, the interior solution analyzed is not valid when @xmath12, and the vanishing of normal curvatures on the bounding surface suggests but does not prove a plane source. The LC spacetime has no horizons, indicating an upper limit to the mass per unit length of line sources. An anisotropic fluid with @xmath19 matched to LC produces an effective mass per unit length that has a maximum at @xmath20, which might explain the inexistence of horizons.

• Quantum information processing has gained significant interest due to the potential of quantum computers.
• Deutsch's investigations on quantum computers sparked this interest.
• Quantum information can be stored and processed in quantum systems, such as qubits.
• Quantum channels transmit quantum information from one party (Alice) to another (Bob).
• The channel's action on qubits can be described by a completely positive linear map (CP-map).
• Alice and Bob can estimate the channel's parameters using various protocols.
• The quality of these estimation protocols can be quantified using statistical and fidelity-based cost functions.

• The study presents a two-component model (tcm) for hadron production in high-energy nuclear collisions, describing soft (projectile dissociation) and hard (parton fragmentation to minimum-bias dijets) components.
• The tcm accurately describes most fs hadron yield and spectrum systematics, while the nj quadrupole plays a major role in 2d angular correlations and is measurable even for peripheral collisions.
• The study extends the tcm to include a nj quadrupole component, establishing its dependence on centrality and exploring its correspondence with centrality, underlying event (ue) structure, dijet production, and the partonic structure of projectile protons.
• The study also presents a tcm for pseudorapidity densities and the pseudorapidity-acceptance dependence of transverse-rapidity spectra.

<summary>
* The principle of quantum superposition is crucial in quantum mechanics and its destruction and preservation are key issues in quantum-to-classical transition and technological applications.
* The loss of coherence in quantum systems is due to the action of the environment, which can be mathematically treated using master equations.
* The authors develop a novel approach to derive master equations using stochastic methods and operator techniques, both in Markovian and non-Markovian regimes.
* The main result is that any Lindblad-type master equation, with self-adjoint Lindblad operators, can be understood as an averaged random unitary evolution.
* The authors discuss mathematical consequences, such as a fast method to solve master equations, and physical implications, such as the origin of the Lindbladian structure and the possibility of intrinsic decoherence.
</summary>

• In the standard cosmological model, ordinary matter (baryonic) makes up only 4% of the total mass-energy, with 23% being non-baryonic dark matter and 73% being mysterious dark energy.
• Dark matter is inferred from the rotation curves of galaxies and the bending of light, but its nature is unknown. It is believed to be composed of weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs).
• The standard model of particle physics does not account for dark matter or dark energy. However, extensions like supersymmetry or extra dimensions offer potential candidates for dark matter particles.
• Dark energy is thought to be a constant energy density that permeates all of space-time, possibly related to Einstein's cosmological constant. Its small value is a mystery.
• The standard model of cosmology, known as the Lambda-CDM model, successfully explains the cosmic microwave background radiation and the large-scale structure of the universe, but the nature of dark matter and dark energy remains unknown.

* The source document discusses the behavior of polyampholytes (PAs) in different dimensions, focusing on their phase diagrams and ground state properties.
* The document mentions previous work on PAs in 1D and 2D, as well as Monte Carlo (MC) simulations for PAs in 3D.
* The authors explore the phase diagrams of quenched PAs in d dimensions, finding that for d=8, the behavior of PAs is similar to that of random chains with short-range interactions.
* For d=9, the spatial conformations of a PA strongly depend on its excess charge, with a critical charge such that PAs with larger excess charges cannot form a compact state.
* The document also discusses the ground states of annealed PAs, finding that the optimal configurations correspond to a uniform distribution of excess charge along the backbone.

• The paper discusses the reflection of X-ray radiation off the surface of cold disks in active galactic nuclei (AGN) and galactic black holes (GBHs).
• It focuses on the effects of photoionization and compton scattering on the reflected continuum and iron fluorescence lines.
• The authors calculate the temperature structure and emission lines via radiative recombination and reflection due to resonance line scattering from the derived layers.

* Polymers with contour length much larger than persistence length are flexible and described by quantum mechanics and quantum field theory.
* As chain length decreases, stiffness becomes important and flexible polymer models may not apply.
* The Kratky-Porod model is a standard coarse-graining model for wormlike polymers, with penalty for bending energy and local inextensibility.
* There has been significant interest in studying semiflexible polymers in recent years, with applications in biology and semicrystalline polymers.
* Recent work has shown that the transverse distribution function of a 2D polymer has a bimodal shape for short polymers, indicating semiflexibility.
* This paper studies the transverse distribution function of a 3D wormlike chain with a fixed orientation of one end using an exact representation.
* The exact solution of the Green's function allows for computing quantities such as the structure factor and end-to-end distribution function.
* Practically exact calculations demonstrate that the transverse distribution function has a bimodal shape in the intermediate range of chain lengths.
* Analytical results for short and long wormlike chains are presented, agreeing with previous results obtained by different methods.
* The paper is organized into sections for formalism and analytical considerations, numerical computations, and discussion of results.
</summary>

<summary>
* A graph is closed if and only if it is chordal, claw-free, and narrow.
* Closed graphs are characterized by properties of their binomial edge ideals.
* The paper proves that a graph is closed if and only if it is chordal, claw-free, and narrow.
* The algorithm for labeling connected graphs is used to prove this theorem.
* The labeling produced by the algorithm is closed when the input graph is chordal, claw-free, and narrow.
* The proof uses induction on the number of vertices in the graph.
