* The base case is proved by showing that the labeling produced by the algorithm is complete and an interval.
* The inductive step is proved by showing that if the labeling produced by the algorithm is complete and an interval for all vertices with smaller labels, then it is also complete and an interval for the next vertex.
* The paper also characterizes closed graphs using the clique complex of the graph.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Cosmic Rays and Their Spectrum**: Cosmic rays are elementary particles arriving at Earth from space, discovered in the early 20th century. They have a featureless power law energy spectrum, decreasing as the cube of the primary energy. The high energy tail of the spectrum corresponds to energies up to 3 x 10^20 eV, with rates of a few particles per km^2 per century. The spectrum has no observed Greisen-Zatsepin-Kuzmin (GZK) cutoff, and there's no firm evidence of anisotropy.
* **Composition and Acceleration**: The composition of cosmic rays is crucial for understanding their origin. They could be accelerated through stochastic acceleration at interfaces between regions with different bulk motions, or be decay products of other particles. Accelerated particles are expected to have a different composition than decay products, with ratios of photons to nucleons depending on the source distribution.
* **Air Showers and Inclined Showers**: Air showers are produced when cosmic rays interact with Earth's atmosphere, and they have traditionally been studied at close to vertical incidence. Inclined showers, induced by high energy neutrinos, can also be analyzed, nearly doubling the aperture of air shower arrays and aiding in the study of primary composition. A model has been developed to understand the muon density patterns produced by inclined showers under the influence of Earth's magnetic field.
* **Haverah Park Array and Photon Composition**: The Haverah Park array, using water Cherenkov tanks, has been used to study inclined showers. A two-component proton-photon scenario suggests that the photon component of the integral spectrum above 4 x 10^19 eV must be less than 10% at the 90% confidence level, providing a robust bound on the photon composition at ultra-high energies.
</summary>

• **Optical Lattices and Cold Atoms**: Optical lattices are artificial crystals of light created by interfering laser beams, trapping cold atoms in periodic potential wells.
• **Bose-Einstein Condensation (BEC)**: BEC is a physical state where a significant number of bosons occupy the same quantum state, observed in ultracold atomic gases.
• **Superfluid to Mott Insulator (SF-MI) Transition**: The SF-MI transition is a phase transition where a superfluid becomes a Mott insulator, observed in cold atoms in optical lattices.
• **Double-Well Potential**: A double-well potential is a 1D optical lattice with two wells separated by a barrier, created by superposing two standing waves.
• **Hubbard Model**: The Hubbard model is a single-band lattice model supporting a single atomic state, used to describe the behavior of cold atoms in double-well potentials.
• **Spin Ordering**: Spin ordering refers to the arrangement of spins in a system, which can be studied using the Hubbard model in double-well potentials.
• **Tunneling and Interaction**: In the Hubbard model, atoms can tunnel between wells with a rate 'j' and interact with each other with a strength 'u'.
• **Potential Bias**: A potential bias can be introduced in the double-well potential to control the energy difference between singlet and triplet states.
• **Inter-Site Interactions**: Inter-site interactions, such as inter-site Coulombic interaction and exchange interaction, can be included in the Hubbard model to account for ferromagnetism.
• **Experimental Realization**: The double-well experiment can be realized using laser cooling and trapping techniques, allowing for the study of spin ordering in cold atoms.

• The study investigates the magnetic phase of iron pnictides using a DFT approach, focusing on the compound BaFe2As2 and its electronic structure.
• The calculations reproduce experimental ARPES data well, showing good agreement with the magnetic order and the fermi surface.

<summary>
* **Source and Discovery:** The M31 globular cluster (GC) B158 contains a bright X-ray source, XB158, discovered by the Einstein Observatory and observed in every subsequent X-ray mission.
* **X-ray Variability:** XB158 exhibits strong intensity modulation on a 10017 s (12.78 hr) period, with amplitude decreasing with increasing source intensity. No modulation was found in a 2001 observation, setting a 2% upper limit.
* **Binary Nature and Superhumps:** The 2002 January XMM-Newton observation revealed a single deep dip at the end of the observation, suggesting a precessing disk. This behavior is associated with the "superhump" phenomenon in low mass ratio systems.
* **X-ray Spectrum and Accretor:** The 2004 July XMM-Newton spectrum was modeled with a blackbody and a power law, yielding a photon index of 2.0±0.3, indicating a neutron star accretor. 3D SPH modeling estimated the disk precession period to be 29 times the orbital period.
* **Chandra Monitoring and Swift Observations:** Chandra observations spanning 13 years showed varying accretion rates over the disk precession cycle. A series of 30 Swift observations spaced 1 day apart revealed a super-orbital period of 16 days.
* **Super-orbital Period and Implications:** The observed super-orbital period is 170% longer than predicted by 3D SPH simulations, likely due to a lower mass ratio of the donor to the accretor than assumed. The hard X-ray spectrum and long-term luminosity fluctuations support the hypothesis of a low mass ratio system.
</summary>

* The text discusses various methods to calculate the energy and lifetime of resonance states in quantum systems.
* The complex scaling method is mentioned, which reveals a resonance state by an isolated complex eigenvalue on the spectrum of the non-hermitian complex scaled Hamiltonian.
* The complex virial theorem and graphical methods are used to pick the best numerical solution for a given problem.
* The density of states (DOS) method is used to obtain the energy and lifetime of a resonance state, but it has no single procedure to assess the accuracy and convergence of the findings.
* Pont et al. used finite size scaling arguments to analyze the properties of the DOS when the size of the Hamiltonian changes.
* The text presents a recipe to select certain values of the basis set size and one eigenvalue for each size, based on some properties of the variational spectrum.
* The set of approximate resonance energies obtained from the DOS of a series of eigenvalues selected following the recipe shows a very regular behavior with the basis set size.
* The extrapolated values obtained using finite size scaling arguments are the most accurate approximation for the parameters of the resonance state.

* **Purpose of the paper**: The paper aims to introduce fundamental 2D plaquettes that can be used to construct 2D @xmath0-symmetric lattices in nonlinear optics.
* **Types of plaquettes**: Four basic types of plaquettes are introduced: three 4-site squares and one 5-site cross. These configurations are inspired by earlier works on 2D Hamiltonian lattices described by discrete nonlinear Schrödinger equations.
* **Analysis and findings**: The paper analyzes the spectral properties of the linear subsystems and the existence, stability, and dynamics of stationary modes in the nonlinear systems. It finds that some modes exist past the critical points of the linear systems due to nonlinearity, while others terminate at these points. The stability of the modes is examined, and it is found that most modes are unstable, but stable branches exist as well.
* **Future work**: The paper paves the way for further considerations of 2D and 3D @xmath0-symmetric lattice systems. The next step is to construct periodic 2D lattices of the building blocks presented in the paper and identify their modes. In the 3D realm, the first step is to examine a @xmath0-symmetric cube composed of eight sites and its nonlinear modes.

• **Binary System & Planets**: The cataclysmic variable (CV) Hu Aqr consists of a 0.80 white dwarf accreting from a 0.18 main-sequence companion star. It is orbited by two planets: a 5.7 Earth-mass planet in a 0.04 AU orbit with an eccentricity of 0.26, and a more massive (7.6 Earth-mass) planet in a wider (0.12 AU) and more eccentric (0.42) orbit.
• **Planetary System Stability**: Although the two-planet configuration is dynamically unstable on a 100,000-year timescale, a small fraction of numerical simulations exhibit long-term stability. The presence of planets around a binary, especially a CV, is peculiar but not unprecedented.
• **Evolution & Mass Loss**: The CV's evolution can be constrained using the planets. After the primary star overflowed its Roche lobe, initiating a common-envelope phase, the white dwarf's mass and composition limit the progenitor's mass and evolutionary phase. The inner planet allows for the rate of mass loss in the common envelope to be derived, while the outer planet validates this calculation and determines the CV's birth conditions.
• **Reconstruction & Mass Loss Rate**: By reconstructing the binary's history using the planets, the initial conditions (primary mass, secondary mass, orbital separation, and planetary orbital separations) and the rate of mass loss in the common envelope (@~1.8 x 10^-6 M_sun/yr) were derived. The mass loss rate is consistent with numerical common-envelope studies, and the inner planet formed at ~0.04 AU, consistent with other binary systems.

• The NCSM/RGM approach, combining microscopic cluster techniques with realistic interactions, has been extended to treat three-body cluster systems.
• This extension allows for the study of nuclear systems with three-body cluster structures, such as two-nucleon halo nuclei, resonant systems, and transfer reactions.
• The first results for the ground state of 11Be within a 4He+n+n basis were presented, showing good agreement with NCSM calculations.
• The NCSM/RGM approach provides appropriate asymptotic behavior for the 4He+n+n wave functions, unlike bound-state methods like NCSM.
• Preliminary results for continuum states of 11Be were obtained, including the well-known 1/2+ resonance and a second low-lying 3/2- resonance.
• The NCSM/RGM approach is ideal for studying 11Be states in the continuum, with ongoing work to improve model spaces and study stability.
• Computing support for this work came from various sources, including LLNL, DOE/SC/NP, NERC, and TRIUMF.

• The text discusses the experimental evidence of skyrmions in non-centrosymmetric compounds with Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction.
• MnSi thin films on silicon substrates have been studied for potential spintronic device applications.
• MnSi films offer various magnetic phases and easy integration due to silicon substrate, but have a low magnetic ordering temperature.
• MnGe, a B20 compound with a higher magnetic ordering temperature, is explored as a potential candidate.
• MnGe has a helical spin structure with a helix length between 3 nm and 6 nm, and a large topological Hall effect exceeding that of MnSi.
• The synthesis of MnGe is challenging due to high pressure and temperature requirements, but molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) offers thin film growth under non-equilibrium conditions.
• The text presents a method for growing MnGe thin films on Si substrates using a MnSi seedlayer to realize the B20 crystal structure.
• The structure and morphology of the films were investigated using RHEED, AFM, and XRD.
• Magnetization and magnetoresistance measurements were performed to determine the physical properties of the samples.

• The core entropy of a quadratic polynomial is a measure of its complexity, defined using the dynamics of its associated Julia set. It is a generalization of the entropy theory of real quadratic maps.
• The core entropy function extends continuously from the Mandelbrot set to the complex plane, and its value at a non-real vein of the Mandelbrot set is monotone. The restriction of the core entropy to non-real veins of the Mandelbrot set also reconstructs the lamination for the Mandelbrot set.

• **Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRBs) and their Origin**: GRBs are believed to be of cosmological origin, with evidence from the detection of x-ray, optical, and radio afterglows from well-localized events. The fireball model is strongly favored, but the degree of beaming in GRBs is still uncertain.
• **Fireball Model and Energetics**: The fireball model requires ultra-relativistic motion to avoid the compactness problem, with initial Lorentz factors typically greater than 1000. However, the baryon contamination problem may exist in popular progenitor models, leading to the possibility of failed GRBs (FGRBs) with lower Lorentz factors.
• **Failed GRBs (FGRBs)**: FGRBs are baryon-contaminated fireballs with initial Lorentz factors much less than one hundred but still much greater than unity. They can produce prominent afterglows and may be responsible for fast x-ray transients and x-ray-rich GRBs.
• **Orphan Afterglows**: Both FGRBs and jetted but off-axis GRBs can produce isolated fading objects, known as orphan afterglows. The detection of orphan afterglows does not necessarily mean that GRBs are beamed, and distinguishing between the two types is challenging.
• **Distinguishing FGRB and Jetted GRB Orphans**: The light curve of an orphan afterglow can be affected by the uncertainty in the trigger time. By shifting the light curve along the time axis, it is possible to discriminate between FGRB and jetted GRB orphans based on their late-time behavior.
• **Possible Solutions for Trigger Time Uncertainty**: Several methods can help determine the onset of an orphan afterglow, including improving the detection limit, associating the orphan with a fast x-ray transient, observing the rising phase, using radio observations, and detecting gravitational wave or neutrino radiation associated with GRBs.
• **Future Prospects and Limitations**: Measuring the GRB beaming angle using orphan searches is challenging due to the difficulty in deriving a satisfactory light curve for an orphan afterglow. However, following fast x-ray transients and x-ray-rich GRBs can provide valuable information on FGRBs and help test the fireball model under different conditions.

• **Gamma-Ray Burst Observations**: The text discusses two gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) observed by the XMM-Newton satellite: GRB 011211 and GRB 001025.
• **GRB 011211**: This GRB was detected by the BeppoSAX satellite and localized on 2001 December 11. Its afterglow was observed by XMM-Newton, showing a power-law spectrum with a photon index of 2.16 and no significant spectral evolution.
• **GRB 001025**: This GRB was detected by the RXTE All-Sky Monitor on 2000 October 25. XMM-Newton observed a bright source in its error box, which is likely the GRB's afterglow, showing a power-law spectrum with a photon index of 2.01.
• **X-Ray Spectra and Absorption**: The X-ray spectra of both GRBs are featureless, with no significant absorption above the galactic value. This lack of absorption is consistent with the lack of detected reddening in the optical afterglow of GRB 011211.

<summary>
* AI3, a layered organic material, has recently gained interest due to its low-energy massless Dirac fermions under high pressure.
* Unlike graphene, AI3 has tilted Dirac cones, anisotropy in the Fermi surface, and a smaller Fermi velocity.
* Electronic correlations are relevant in AI3 due to its larger effective coupling constant for electron-electron interactions.
* Massive carriers exist near the Fermi level in AI3, but their interplay with Dirac fermions was not proven experimentally.
* The study presents magneto-transport measurements of AI3 crystals under high pressure (>3 GPa) where Dirac carriers are present.
* Both high-mobility Dirac carriers and low-mobility massive holes are observed, confirming the coexistence of both carrier types.
* The mobilities of both carrier types hint at scattering mechanisms due to strongly screened interaction potentials or other short-range scatterers.
* The carrier densities follow the expected temperature dependence for both massless Dirac fermions and massive carriers.
* Thermopower measurements support the two-carrier scenario, with a sign change indicating different charge carriers at low and high temperatures.
* The study highlights the importance of considering both Dirac and massive carriers in AI3, with Dirac carriers dominating at low magnetic fields and high temperatures, and massive holes driving conduction at high magnetic fields and low temperatures.
</summary>

• The article discusses the spin response of iron-based superconductors (FEBS) with two different superconducting gap scales. Spin resonance appears in the sign-changing gap state (s-wave) below the indirect gap scale, which is determined by the sum of gaps on two different Fermi surface sheets connected by the scattering wave vector. The indirect gap can be either the smaller or larger gap scale, depending on the Fermi surface geometry. The peak in the dynamical spin susceptibility at the wave vector is the true spin resonance if it appears below the indirect gap scale.
• The article compares energy scales extracted from various experimental techniques for most materials and concludes that the observed feature in inelastic neutron scattering is the spin resonance peak. However, it is not always clear which gaps are connected by the wave vector, and definitive conclusions can only be drawn from the calculation of the dynamical spin susceptibility for the particular experimental band structure.
• The article presents a table of peak frequencies and maximal and minimal gap sizes available in the literature for various materials. It concludes that the peak in inelastic neutron scattering is the true spin resonance evidencing the sign-changing gap in many electron-doped and some hole-doped materials. However, the calculation of the spin response for the particular experimental band structure is required to make a final conclusion.

• The presence of impurities in a quantum system significantly alters its spectrum and coherence properties. In one and two dimensions, all states are exponentially localized in the absence of interactions, while a mobility edge exists in three dimensions.
• The authors introduce a two-dimensional generalization of the dual random dimer model (2d-drdm), where impurities cannot be first neighbors and each impurity modifies the hopping with its nearest neighbor sites. They show that, in the non-interacting regime, there exists a resonance energy at which the structured impurity is transparent and the states around this energy are delocalized.
• The authors then consider the case of a weakly interacting Bose gas confined on such a potential and show that the disorder induced by the 2d-drdm drives the homogeneity of the ground state. The condensate fraction exhibits a non-monotonic behavior as a function of the disorder strength, with an enhancement in correspondence of the resonance energy of the 2d-drdm single-particle Hamiltonian.

• The paper studies the maximum independent set problem for generalized Petersen graphs.
• An upper bound for even @xmath8 is provided, which is better than previous bounds.
• Lower bounds for even @xmath8 and odd @xmath7 are given, with exact values for some cases.
• The independence number of generalized Petersen graphs with fixed @xmath8 can be found in linear time.

• The paper proposes two phase encoding MDIQKD schemes.
• The first scheme uses phase locking of two separate laser sources.
• The second scheme converts phase encoding into polarization encoding.
• Both schemes are proven to be unconditionally secure against the most general attacks.
• The security proof assumes nothing about the measurement performed by the middle unit (MU).
• The key generation rate is simulated using realistic parameters.
• The first scheme can cover shorter distances and may require less accuracy of the state preparation.
• The second scheme can cover much longer distances when the state preparation is very precise.
• The imperfection of the phase modulators is a significant factor affecting the key generation rate.
• The accurate preparation of the states is crucial for the security of both MDIQKD and standard QKD.

<summary>
* Massive stars play a crucial role in galaxy evolution, but their formation process remains uncertain.
* Recent high-resolution observations suggest that massive stars form via accretion, similar to low-mass stars.
* Methanol masers trace regions of massive star formation and are associated with hot molecular cores.
* The authors observed three hot molecular cores at mid-infrared wavelengths to uncover embedded sources.
* They found multiple point sources, with the brightest one closest to methanol masers, and calculated the likelihood of forming the observed massive stars from the available gas.
</summary>

• **Modified Gravity and Dark Energy**: Modified theories of gravity, like @xmath0 theory, are explored to understand the enigmatic dark energy driving the universe's accelerated expansion. These theories modify Einstein-Hilbert action by adding or replacing curvature invariants.

• **@xmath0 Theory of Gravity**: This theory couples the Gauss-Bonnet invariant with a scalar field or a generic function in the Einstein-Hilbert action. It yields a non-zero covariant divergence of the energy-momentum tensor, leading to non-geodesic trajectories for massive test particles.

• **Cosmological Reconstruction**: The paper reconstructs various cosmological models, including de Sitter universe, power-law solutions, phantom/non-phantom eras, and @xmath13cdm model, in the @xmath0 theory of gravity using the reconstruction technique.

• **Stability Analysis**: The stability of de Sitter and power-law solutions against linear homogeneous perturbations is analyzed. The field equation and continuity equation are perturbed, and their numerical solutions provide stable/unstable results.

• **Stability Results for De Sitter Universe**: Models ( [6d] ) and ( [9d] ) are found to be stable against linear perturbations, while model ( [5d] ) is unstable.

• **Stability Results for Power-Law Universe**: @xmath0 gravity fails to reproduce matter and radiation-dominated eras. Stable results are obtained for the accelerated phase of the universe for model ( [5p] ).

• **Majorana Fermions (MFs) and Their Detection:**
  - MFs are real solutions of the Dirac equation, proposed as neutrino models and now predicted in engineered condensed matter systems.
  - They obey non-Abelian statistics, crucial for decoherence-free quantum computation and quantum information processing.
  - Recent focus is on topological superconductors as platforms for hosting MFs, with various realistic systems proposed, including topological insulators, semiconductor nanowires, and atomic chains.
  - MFs are their own antiparticles and appear in tunneling spectroscopy experiments as zero-bias peaks.

• **Challenges in MF Detection:**
  - Observing unique MF signatures experimentally is challenging due to other mechanisms causing zero-bias peaks, such as Kondo resonance and disorder-induced band bending.
  - Distinguishing MFs from conventional fermionic subgap states is difficult, and most experimental evidence relies on tunneling conductance measurements.

• **Proposed Optical Detection Scheme:**
  - An alternative all-optical scheme is proposed to detect MFs using a coupled hybrid quantum dot (QD) - nanomechanical resonator (NR) system with optical pump-probe technology.
  - The scheme avoids direct contact between MFs and the hybrid system, minimizing disturbances in MF detection.

• **Hybrid QD-NR System and Couplings:**
  - The QD is modeled as a two-level system, and the NR as a quantum harmonic oscillator.
  - The system includes two kinds of couplings: QD-MF coupling and QD-NR coupling.
  - MFs are described using an operator with Majorana representation, and the QD-MF coupling is due to dipole-dipole interaction.

• **Optical Pump-Probe Technology:**
  - The optical pump-probe technology involves a strong pump laser and a weak probe laser.
  - The strong pump laser stimulates the system to generate coherent optical effects, while the weak probe laser observes linear and nonlinear optical effects.

• **Hamiltonian and Langevin Equations:**
  - The Hamiltonian of the exciton of the QD coupled to the two fields is derived, and the total Hamiltonian of the system is obtained in a rotating frame at the pump field frequency.
  - The quantum Langevin equations of the whole system are derived, including the exciton spontaneous emission rate, dephasing rate, decay rates of the NR and MF, and correlated Langevin noise operators.

• **Numerical Results and Majorana Signature:**
  - The coherent optical properties of the QD

* The first evidence of time reversal symmetry violation was found in the kaon system.
* No other signal of time reversal symmetry violation has been found to date.
* Studying time reversal symmetry has become a cornerstone of searching for physics beyond the standard model.
* Some alternatives or extensions of the standard model imply specific ways of time reversal violation.
* These theories are formulated in terms of quarks and leptons, while nuclear low energy tests involve hadronic degrees of freedom.
* Effective one boson exchange potentials are used to relate quark degrees of freedom to hadronic degrees of freedom.
* The charge vector type exchange and the axial vector type exchange nucleon nucleon interaction are considered.
* The purpose of the paper is to estimate hadronic matrix elements that arise when relating quark operators to effective hadronic parameterizations of the time-even, charge-odd interaction.

• Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) are used as standard candles for measuring distances due to their uniform light curves and lack of hydrogen but strong silicon lines in their spectra at maximum brightness. A plausible explosion model for SNe Ia is the accreting white dwarf (WD) model, where a WD in a binary system accretes material from its companion star, increases its mass, and eventually explodes.
• The companion star of a SN Ia can be identified by searching for absorption lines with broad blue wings in its spectrum. This is because when a star is inside the ejecta of a SN Ia, photons emitted from the star are absorbed only by the ejecta moving toward us, resulting in a broad wing present only in the blue side of the absorption line. The amount of Fe I in the ejecta of Tycho's SN can be estimated by considering collisional processes and ionizations by photons emitted from the shocked ejecta.

• **Quantum Entanglement**: Quantum entanglement is a feature of quantum mechanics that allows for the creation of a physical resource, which can be manipulated independently of its physical realization and obeys conservation laws.
• **Entanglement Measures**: To quantify entanglement, various measures have been proposed, such as the entropy of entanglement and the entanglement of formation, which provide a lower bound for the amount of entanglement in a system.
• **Entanglement in Open Systems**: In open systems, entanglement is more complex to quantify due to the inherent uncertainty surrounding a mixed state. The partial trace with respect to the environment yields a mixed state for the bipartite system, which may not provide a complete description of the entanglement.
• **Quantum Trajectory Unravelings**: To address this issue, nha and carmichael introduced a measure of entanglement for open systems based upon quantum trajectory unravelings of the open system dynamics. This approach considers the way in which information about the system is read from the environment, allowing for a more complete characterization of the entanglement.

• The unification scheme of AGN explains the difference between Type 1 and Type 2 AGN through angle-dependent circumnuclear obscuration by a dusty medium, or "dust torus".
• The dust torus absorbs UV/optical radiation and re-emits it in the infrared, with Type 1 AGN showing more near-IR emission than Type 2 AGN for the same intrinsic luminosity.
• The authors study the wavelength dependence of this anisotropy in the infrared using an isotropically selected and complete sample of quasars and radio galaxies with hidden quasars at z~0.5.
• They find that the ratio of Type 1 to Type 2 AGN emission decreases from 20 to 2 between 2 and 8 µm, increases within the 10 µm silicate feature, and becomes more isotropic at longer wavelengths.
• The intrinsic ratio between Type 1 and Type 2 AGN at 15 µm is ~1.4, which should be considered when using IR-selected, flux-limited samples.
• The authors discuss their results in the context of other anisotropy estimators, finding consistency with upper limits from the X-ray/IR correlation of local Seyfert galaxies.
• They suggest that the observed anisotropy is consistent with a clumpy torus model, rather than a smooth one, and discuss the implications for AGN unification and obscuration.

• The paper discusses the security of continuous-variable quantum key distribution (CVQKD) systems, focusing on the local oscillator (LO) intensity fluctuations.
• In practical implementations, the LO is also within Eve's manipulating domain, potentially leaving security loopholes.
• The paper proposes an attacking scheme exploiting LO intensity fluctuations and analyzes its impact on secret key rates for reverse and direct reconciliation protocols.
• Without monitoring or scaling measurements with instantaneous LO intensity values, Bob's estimation of secret key rates can be severely compromised.
• Eve can hide her attack partially or even steal total secret keys by reducing LO intensity, especially for reverse reconciliation.
• Accurate monitoring of LO intensity is crucial for confirming the security of practical CVQKD implementations, posing a challenge for highly accurate monitoring.
• The paper uses an entangling cloner model to calculate the Holevo bound obtained by Eve for direct and reverse reconciliation, confirming the impact of LO intensity attacks on secret key rates.

• **Code Development and Purpose:**
  - The code was developed to efficiently compute adiabatic oscillation frequencies and eigenfunctions for general stellar models.
  - It emphasizes accuracy and offers flexibility in integration methods and determining frequencies within a given degree and frequency range.
  - The code's development was inspired by previous work and aims to provide a simple and efficient tool for stellar oscillation calculations.

• **Equilibrium Model and Variables:**
  - The equilibrium model is defined using a minimal set of dimensionless variables, along with mass and radius.
  - Key variables include distance to the center, mass interior to that distance, photospheric radius and mass, gravitational constant, pressure, density, and their derivatives.
  - The code also defines characteristic frequencies and the dimensionless sound speed.

• **Oscillation Equations and Boundary Conditions:**
  - The equations of adiabatic stellar oscillations are expressed in terms of dependent variables chosen for numerical stability.
  - Boundary conditions are applied at the center, surface, and, in some cases, an inner fitting point.
  - The code uses a shooting method or relaxation technique to solve the differential equations and find eigenvalues (frequencies).

• **Code Features and Improvements:**
  - The code allows for the computation of modes of arbitrarily high degree and order.
  - It includes options for improving precision, such as a variational principle and Richardson extrapolation.
  - The code can output eigenfunctions and normalized inertia, providing insights into the mode's characteristics.
  - Ongoing developments include a fourth-order integration scheme, using lagrangian pressure perturbation as a variable, and improved classification of dipolar modes.

<summary>
* The text discusses the manifestation of jet instabilities in creating bubble-shaped features in normal spirals and radio galaxies, which could potentially explain the origin of hi supershells in disk galaxies.
* The model proposes that radio jets ejected close to the plane of the disk during an active nuclear phase encounter regions of large-scale density decline near the outskirts of the galactic disk, causing the jets to flare and inflate bubbles of hot plasma that expand and sweep up the gas-rich ambient medium into the shape of hi supershells.
* The model is applied to the edge-on spiral galaxy NGC 3556, which exhibits two prominent supershells located symmetrically near the opposite extremities of the galaxy. The model can account for the observed features of these supershells, including their large energy requirements and the lack of evidence for other explanations such as starburst-induced superwinds or infall of external gas clouds.
</summary>

• **Leo I's Stellar Populations:**
  - Star formation has occurred continuously from at least 10-15 billion years ago to less than 1 billion years ago.
  - A lack of a prominent horizontal branch suggests a small fraction of very old stars, indicating delayed star formation compared to other dwarf spheroidal galaxies.

• **Metallicity and Age Range:**
  - The width of Leo I's red giant branch can be attributed to the age dispersion of its stellar population, implying a negligible metallicity dispersion.
  - The metallicity range is estimated to be between 0.0001 and 0.004, increasing with time.

* The paper presents a result on the principal eigenvalue of the fractional Laplacian on a bounded domain with Dirichlet boundary conditions, perturbed by a divergence-free vector field. The result is a generalization of a previous result for the classical Laplacian.
* The main theorem states that the principal eigenvalue remains bounded as the perturbation parameter tends to infinity if and only if the vector field has a nontrivial first integral. The proof uses the Krein-Rutman theorem and compactness arguments, and the result is applied to study the influence of a fluid flow on a diffusion process.

• **Phase Transitions and Machine Learning**: The text discusses the application of machine learning, specifically unsupervised learning algorithms like principal component analysis (PCA) and variational autoencoders (VAEs), to identify phase transitions in physical systems without prior knowledge of the order parameter.
• **Ising Model Analysis**: The authors test these methods on the Ising model, a well-studied model in physics, and find that the first principal component or the latent parameter from the autoencoder closely approximates the known order parameter, the magnetization.
• **Phase Transition Identification**: They demonstrate that the reconstruction loss, a measure of how well the autoencoder can reconstruct the input data from its latent representation, can serve as a universal indicator for phase transitions.
• **Future Applications**: The authors suggest that these techniques could be used to predict unseen phases or uncover unknown order parameters in complex systems, such as quantum spin liquids, and that deep convolutional autoencoders could further enhance these capabilities.

• Quantum cloning machines (QCMs) can approximate the copying of quantum states, with different designs depending on the desired outcome and application.
• The paper discusses a "partial" QCM that copies only one part of a two-partite state, and explores its application to mixed states through the concept of "purification".

• The nature of dark matter remains one of the outstanding questions in modern astrophysics, with the cold dark matter cosmological model suggesting a major component in the form of an elementary particle.
• However, the inventory of baryons observed locally falls short of the total inferred from observations of the cosmic microwave background fluctuations, leaving open the possibility of a significant baryonic component of dark matter.
• Some authors have proposed models featuring dense gas clouds as a major component of dark matter, with a variety of different forms considered, including isolated, clustered, and fractal.
• One of the fundamental predictions of these models is the emission of gamma rays resulting from cosmic ray interactions within the clouds, which could yield a diffuse flux comparable to the flux from known sources for photon energies around 1 GeV.
• Previous investigations of this problem have often neglected self-shielding and cascade phenomena, which can be important at high column densities, and have employed emissivities appropriate to the low-density limit.
• The authors present detailed calculations of the gamma-ray spectra arising from cosmic ray interactions with dense gas clouds using a Monte Carlo simulation code, GEANT4, finding significant differences between high and low column density clouds.

<summary>
* Colloidal suspensions can form novel materials via self-assembly, with colloidal crystals generating iridescent colors and photonic crystals.
* The well-defined thermodynamic temperature of colloidal dispersions allows them to be viewed as mesoscopic model atoms.
* Tuning colloid-colloid interactions leads to various structures, including exotic crystal structures not observed in atomic and molecular systems.
* External control of colloid-colloid interactions allows direct observation of phase transitions.
* Direct microscopic observation at the single-particle level provides unprecedented detail for studying long-standing problems in condensed matter, such as freezing.
* A rotating ac field induces dipolar interactions, leading to attractions in the plane of rotation and repulsions above and below.
* Previous work showed that lattice spacing within quasi-2D colloidal crystals could be controlled in situ using a coplanar rotating electric field.
* The interparticle dipolar interactions in the plane of the electric field can be treated as a circularly symmetric attraction due to the time-averaging effect of a rapidly rotating field.
* A simple numerical treatment is used to predict the lattice spacing in the quasi-2D crystal from the electric field strength.
* The effective colloid-colloid interaction is used to compare experimental measurements of the crystal lattice constant with Monte Carlo simulations.
</summary>

• Aql X-1, a soft X-ray transient, was observed to transition from an outburst to quiescence, with a sharp decay and spectral hardening.
• The transition is likely due to the neutron star entering the propeller regime, followed by a transition to the radio pulsar regime, making Aql X-1 a potential link between LMXBs and recycled millisecond pulsars.

• The source document discusses a supernova (SN) explosion model of a Wolf-Rayet star that explains the bolometric and X-ray light curves (LCs) of SN 2006jc.
• The progenitor star of SN 2006jc is a Wolf-Rayet star with a carbon-rich envelope and circumstellar matter (CSM), consistent with the formation of amorphous carbon grains in the SN ejecta and CSM.
• The explosion and bolometric LC of SN 2006jc are powered by the decay of 44Ti-44Co, and the X-ray emission is due to the interaction between the SN ejecta and the CSM.
• The CSM density structure is derived from a comparison with the observed X-ray LC, and the flat density distribution in the inner CSM indicates a drastic change in the mass-loss rate and/or wind velocity.

* <summary>
* GRB 1915+105 is a unique black hole binary (BHB) exhibiting extreme variability and rapid state changes.
* IGR J17091+3624, another BHB, has shown similar variability patterns to GRB 1915+105, including 'heartbeat' oscillations.
* The apparent faintness of IGR J17091+3624 is likely due to its low or negative spin, as suggested by simultaneous spectral fitting.
* The 'heartbeat' oscillations can be used as a 'standard candle' to constrain the parameters of IGR J17091+3624.
* The black hole in IGR J17091+3624 may have a retrograde spin, making it the first known astrophysical source with such a spin. </summary>

• The extinction curve describes how extinction changes with wavelength due to dust grains in the interstellar medium, with different characteristics in diffuse and dense media.
• The knowledge of the extinction curve is necessary for dereddening magnitudes and colors of astronomical objects and understanding the physical properties of dust grains.
• Cardelli, Clayton, and Mathis (CCM) derived a mean extinction law depending on a single parameter, Rv, using a sample of reddened Milky Way OB stars.
• The CCM law allows determining extinction in one spectral region based on extinction in another, given the value of Rv.
• Rv ranges from about 2.0 to 5.5, characterizing dust properties in the region producing the extinction.
• Many authors have used Rv to study extinction, and the authors extend the method used by Fitzpatrick and Massa (1990) to obtain improved Rv values for a sample of stars with known extinction data in the UV.

• The text discusses the construction of ranking toric modules, which are used to compute the rank jump of a weakly toric module at a fixed parameter. These modules are constructed via their degree sets, which are unions of translated lattices contained in the ranking lattices of the module.
• The text also introduces the concept of a simple ranking toric module, which is a ranking toric module with a specific structure. These modules are used to decompose the euler koszul homology of a ranking toric module into simpler pieces, which can be computed more easily.

* <summary>Quantum computers use qubits, which can be realized using semiconductor quantum dots with controlled electron numbers. The qubit state can be encoded using electron charge or spin, with spin qubits being more robust due to longer decoherence times.</summary>
* <summary>Manipulation of qubits can be done using electron spin resonance, and read-out can be achieved via currents in spin-polarized leads. Another concept is based on singlet-triplet states in a double quantum dot, where magnetic fields are not necessary, and qubit preparation is performed by electrical control of exchange interactions.</summary>
* <summary>In this paper, the authors propose a qubit based on a triangular triple quantum dot (tqd) system, where qubit states are encoded in the doublet subspace and controlled by exchange interactions. The qubit states can be read out using a doublet blockade effect, which manifests itself in currents for a specific configuration of local potential gates.</summary>

• Symbiotic systems (SS) consist of a white dwarf (WD), a red giant (RG), and circumstellar/circumbinary nebulae, emitting radiation from radio to X-rays.
• Z Andromedae (Z And) is an SS with a cool giant of spectral type M4.5 and a hot compact component with a temperature of ~1.5 x 10^5 K.
• The 1984-1986 event in Z And was characterized by two maxima in the visual magnitude, leading to ambiguous interpretations of a double or disturbed single outburst.
• The brightness of the 1984-1986 event was low but well-monitored, allowing detailed spectral modeling of the system's physical conditions.
• The stellar wind of the cool giant has a velocity of ~25 km/s, and an optically thick wind forms from the WD, with shocks from wind collision increasing the system's luminosity.
• The wind collision model was used to calculate line spectra, with input parameters including shock velocity, preshock density, magnetic field, WD temperature, ionization parameter, nebula thickness, dust-to-gas ratio, and abundances of various elements.
• The modeling of the 1984-1986 spectra revealed unexpected trends in physical conditions, with collision of the WD wind with RG shells and sudden changes in the ionization parameter and shock velocity.

• **SwCNT Networks for Electrical Applications**: SwCNT networks are emerging as novel materials for electronic applications, requiring accurate determination of their fundamental electrical properties.
• **Two-Dimensional Network of Conducting Rods**: These networks can be viewed as a two-dimensional network of conducting one-dimensional rods, which are either metallic or semiconducting.
• **Randomly Distributed Barriers**: The nanotube-nanotube junction resistance is much larger than the nanotube resistance itself, making the network a system with randomly distributed barriers for electrical transport.
• **Percolation Behavior**: For sub-monolayer networks, the junction resistance dominates the overall resistance, showing percolation behavior with nonlinear thickness dependence.
• **Metallic Behavior**: For thicker films with tens of nanometers in thickness, the conductance through the metallic tubes dominates, leading to metallic behavior of the overall resistance.
• **Previous Studies**: Previous studies have investigated the frequency-dependent and electric-field-dependent conductivity of individual SWCNTs and some types of SWCNT networks.
• **Current Study**: This study investigates the frequency- and electric-field-dependent conductivity of SWCNT networks with systematically varying densities.
• **Onset Frequency and Length Scale**: The onset frequency extracted from the frequency dependence measurement increases with film thickness, while the length scale extracted from the electric field dependent measurement decreases with thickness.
• **Empirical Relation**: Using the measured onset frequency and extracted length scale, an empirical relation between the two transport measurement methods is developed.

• **Quantum Algorithms Efficiency**: Quantum algorithms, such as Grover's, can perform certain tasks more efficiently than classical algorithms due to quantum superposition and interference. For instance, searching an item in an unsorted database of size N can be done in O(√N) steps using Grover's algorithm, compared to O(N) steps classically.
• **Grover's Algorithm Implementation**: Grover's algorithm has been realized using various physical systems like NMR, superconducting qubits, and atom-cavity QED systems. The algorithm involves a quadratic advantage over its classical counterpart, making it a significant advancement in quantum computing.
• **Superconducting Qubits for Grover's Algorithm**: Superconducting qubits, such as squids, are an attractive approach for implementing quantum algorithms due to their strong coupling limit in microwave cavities compared to atoms in cavity QED. Recent studies have demonstrated the implementation of two-qubit Grover and Deutsch-Jozsa algorithms, as well as the preparation and measurement of three-qubit entanglement using superconducting qubits.

<summary>
* In the 1970s, many-body theory flourished, with a focus on many-body effects in XPS (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy) spectra from deep core levels in metals.
* Related effects included singularities near edges in absorption and emission spectra.
* The CB (conduction band) electrons could have many different effects on the XPS peak from the core level, depending on whether the excitation was adiabatic or swift.
* In the adiabatic approximation, the screening of the core hole by the CB electrons led to a shift of the peak to higher kinetic energy.
* In the sudden approximation, the excitation was swift, and the CB electrons were left in a non-equilibrium state, leading to shake-up effects in the form of single particle and collective excitations.
* The electrons contributing to the shake-up effects were the electrons in the valence and conduction bands.
* The many-body effects showed up as plasmon replicas in the spectrum, with the main peak at the adiabatic position and smaller replicas shifted by the plasma frequency.
</summary>

• The article studies a two-genotype system with nonlinear frequency-dependent selection and asymmetric mutation rates.
• The dynamics are modeled using the Moran process and analyzed via the Fokker-Planck equation.
• The study finds that these factors can induce complex evolutionary dynamics, including multiple stable points and stochastic switching.

<summary>
* The phase-field method is popular due to its algorithmic simplicity and ability to avoid tracking moving interfaces or grain boundaries.
* The method has been used to simulate microstructure formation during solidification, with recent reviews discussing its foundations and applications.
* The thin-interface limit of two-sided phase-field models has been examined, showing that the currently available approaches cannot eliminate all effects linked to the finite interface thickness.
* Orientation-field models for polycrystalline solidification have been discussed, showing that the standard equation of motion for the orientation field is not appropriate for the evolution of coherent crystalline matter.
* The inclusion of microscopic fluctuations in the phase-field equations has been reviewed, showing that the standard approach cannot be used in a straightforward way to investigate the process of nucleation.
* The common point of these topics is that they pose challenges or limitations for straightforward computations, and a detailed mathematical analysis is often required to understand the detailed properties of the phase-field method.
* The precision and performance of phase-field models have been greatly enhanced in the last decade by a detailed control of their properties, with the privileged tool being the thin-interface limit.
* Phase-field models are rooted in the mean-field description of spatially diffuse interfaces by order parameters, but need to bridge the scale gap between the thickness of the physical solid-liquid interfaces and the typical scale of the microstructures.
* The size and shape of the crystalline grains formed upon solidification are important factors determining materials properties, and phase-field models must be capable of dealing with the evolution of polycrystals.
</summary>

• The fundamental atmospheric and physical parameters of stars are crucial for studying the Milky Way and other galaxies in the local group.
• Spectroscopic surveys like SEGUE, RAVE, Gaia-ESO, and HERMES provide data to infer the characteristics of different stellar populations.
• Stellar parameters determined by spectroscopic methods are key, with metallicity only measurable through spectroscopy.
• Atmospheric parameters can be estimated from a spectrum consistently and efficiently, avoiding reddening issues.
• The most common method for deriving spectroscopic atmospheric parameters is using iron (Fe) absorption lines under LTE and HE assumptions.
• However, systematic biases are present due to the breakdown of LTE, with NLTE effects significant at low metallicity and/or surface gravity.
• The authors develop new methods to determine fundamental parameters of FGK stars, applying them to a metal-poor sample from RAVE.

• Weak gravitational lensing effects have been detected in various high redshift sources, including QSOs, galaxies, and GRBs.
• In the case of point sources like QSOs and GRBs, weak lensing manifests as angular correlations with foreground mass distributions.
• For galaxies, weak lensing is detected through its coherent shear effect.
• There is another, more direct way of detecting weak lensing using fluxes of standard candles.
• The best example of cosmological standard candles are Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia), which have been extensively observed to determine the global geometry of the universe.
• Nuisance effects like evolution, variations in individual SNe, and gray dust extinction have been studied and either corrected for or shown to be small.
• Weak lensing, another nuisance effect, has been addressed theoretically and found to be unimportant given current uncertainties.
• The authors of the paper present a study to determine if the observed fluxes of high redshift SNe Ia have suffered significantly from lensing-induced (de-)amplifications.

* The paper presents a theoretical study of heavy fermion (HF) materials using dynamical mean field theory (DMFT) and the local moment approach (LMA) to solve the periodic anderson model (PAM).
* The study focuses on the thermal evolution of single-particle dynamics, scattering rates, d.c. transport, and optical conductivities in the strongly correlated kondo lattice regime.
* The main findings include the universal scaling of single-particle spectra and scattering rates, the thermal evolution of the d.c. resistivity, and the optical conductivity on all relevant energy and temperature scales.

<summary>
* The kinetics of polymer loop formation has been studied for decades, with recent interest due to its importance in biology, particularly in genetic expression, replication, and recombination.
* DNA loop formation is a basic process that underlies these biological functions, and has been observed in experiments using techniques like optical tweezers and magnetic tweezers.
* The hairpin loop formation is the elementary step in protein folding and structure formation in RNA folding, and is also an important process in biology.
* A cell is crowded with a multitude of subcellular structures, including globular proteins and RNAs, with which DNA is constantly interacting, subjecting it to temporally fluctuating forces.
* Recent measurements of the power spectrum of the fluctuating force exerted on the cytoskeleton indicate that the cell interior is an active and nonequilibrium medium.
* Single molecule experiment techniques provide detailed information on DNA loop formation, such as the observation of LacI-mediated DNA loop formation and dissociation by monitoring the nanoscale Brownian motion of a micron-sized particle attached to one end of the DNA.
* The effects of tension in the presence of two-site restriction enzymes, which can cut the DNA upon binding on two sites simultaneously, have been studied, with the cleavage activity decreasing approximately 10-fold as the tension increases from 30 fn to 700 fn.
* The optimum loop size decreases with tension, which is qualitatively in agreement with theoretical predictions.
* More recently, the effects of tension in the femtonewton range on the kinetics of LacI-mediated DNA looping have been studied, with small tension of 100 fn scale on the substrate DNA increasing the looping time, and the looping time being greatly reduced in the presence of a fluctuating tension.
* These results suggest the ubiquitous roles of static and temporally fluctuating tensions in the regulation of DNA loop formation.
* However, there appears to be no unifying conceptual or theoretical framework that explains a variety of experiments including these.
* Theoretically, a transfer matrix method has been developed to calculate the semiflexible polymer end-to-end distance distribution function and loop formation probability (or @xmath0-factor).
* This study provides a valuable insight to understand DNA bending on short length scales, which has attracted much attention recently.
* The effects of tension on the @xmath0-factor have also been studied, which is related to the free energy barrier for loop formation, thus to the loop formation rate.
* Similar results are obtained by using an elastic theory of a semiflexible polymer.
*

<summary>
* The text discusses tidal interactions in close binary systems, focusing on the role of dynamical tides in processes like synchronization, orbital circularization, tidal capture, and planet fall onto the star.
* The study considers the tidal interaction of a star and a point source (planet or star) and investigates the evolution of the star itself, as the evolution time scales of orbital parameters strongly depend on the orbital period.
* The research focuses on three types of stars with masses of one, one and a half, and two solar masses, taking into account their evolution and the simultaneous solution of a large number of ordinary differential equations for each stellar model.
* The overlap integrals, which measure the intensity of tidal interactions, are calculated for each moment of the star's lifetime, along with the time scales of the orbital parameters (tidal quality factor).
* The change in the planet's orbital period is presented as a function of time, taking into account the stellar evolution, and the results are compared with previous studies on tidal interactions and planet fall onto the star.
</summary>

* <summary>
	+ The paper introduces a method to determine the relative distance between two identical incoherent point sources in a disordered environment using intensity fluctuations.
	+ The approach is based on the analysis of the intensity-intensity correlation function and the intensity fluctuations in the speckle pattern formed by the two sources.
	+ The method permits monitoring the relative distance between the sources in the range of 10-500 nm, with a precision not limited by diffraction but by the microstructure of the scattering medium.
	+ The paper also discusses the potential application of this approach to green's function retrieval in complex media, replacing the two-point field-field correlation of the background noise with a measurement at a single point of the intensity noise due to the two fluctuating sources.
* </summary>

• **Cell Mechanics and Cytoskeleton Modeling**: The text discusses the mechanical behavior of cells and the cytoskeleton, focusing on the Glassy Wormlike Chain (GWC) model and its extension to include inelastic effects.
• **GWC Model and Viscoelasticity**: The GWC model describes the mechanics of semiflexible polymers in a network, capturing viscoelastic behavior, slow relaxation, power-law rheology, and shear stiffening. It also accounts for the glassy and fragile nature of cell mechanics.
• **Inelastic Extension and Nonlinear Effects**: The extended GWC model incorporates reversible inelastic behavior, allowing for changes in the fraction of closed bonds and resulting in fluidization, cyclic softening, and inelastic shake-down effects. It also considers the role of prestressing forces and homeostasis in cell mechanics.

<summary>
* Topological properties of time-reversal invariant band insulators have been extensively studied, with a focus on topological insulators characterized by non-trivial topological invariants.
* These insulators have potential applications due to their robust surface metallic states, typically realized in systems with strong spin-orbit interaction.
* All known topological insulators contain heavy or rare metal elements, posing constraints on the search for topological materials.
* Ubiquitous mutual Coulomb repulsions among electrons have been proposed to generate effective spin-orbit couplings, leading to a topological Mott insulator (TMI) in an extended Hubbard model on the honeycomb lattice.
* The TMI phase is unusual due to the emergence of spin-orbit interaction from electronic mutual Coulomb interaction and its unconventional quantum criticality.
* However, the proposed TMI phase has not been achieved in real materials, and its stability against other orders and quantum fluctuations is not clear.
* Reliable examination of stable topological Mott orders in the extended Hubbard model is hampered by competing symmetry breakings such as charge density waves (CDWs).
* In this study, the authors examine the stability of the TMI phase on the honeycomb lattice by controlling the Fermi velocity and employing a variational Monte Carlo method with many variational parameters.
</summary>

<summary>
* Graphene has garnered interest from various communities, with both aiming to gap the massless Dirac spectrum.
* The realization of a gate-induced band gap in Bernal-stacked bilayer graphene brought the holy grail of graphene-based transistors closer to reality.
* However, sub-gap conductance measured in experiments introduced a new puzzle and obstacle: the gapped bilayer is not as insulating as it should be.
* The paper predicts the existence of topological gapless channels of transport along tilt boundary networks, which solves the puzzle and offers the first realization of topological surface/edge states hosted by structural topological defects.
</summary>

• Charged macromolecules, such as polyelectrolytes and polyampholytes, are important in various industrial and medical applications, as well as in biological systems like DNA, RNA, and proteins.
• Polyelectrolytes have charged monomers of the same sign, while polyampholytes have both positively and negatively charged monomers.
• In polyelectrolyte brushes, electrostatic interactions cause counterions to be trapped inside, leading to increased chain stretching and brush alignment.
• In polyampholyte brushes, most counterions are outside the brush, reducing chain size and brush thickness.
• The average thickness of polyampholyte brushes is mainly determined by chain properties, such as charged monomer fraction and sequence, and bending energy.
• The study investigates planar brushes of flexible, semiflexible, and rodlike diblock polyampholytes using molecular dynamics simulations.
• The average brush thickness linearly depends on the grafting density, regardless of chain flexibility, with flexible chains showing a weaker dependence.

<summary>
* The light flavor scalar mesons present a challenge to the naive quark model, with multiple candidates below 2 GeV that cannot be accommodated in one nonet.
* Some of these candidates are believed to be glueballs, molecular states, or tetraquark states.
* The @xmath4 and @xmath5 are good candidates for molecular states, but their cousins @xmath7 and @xmath8 lie considerably higher than the corresponding thresholds.
* The @xmath11 mesons below and above @xmath12 may have different dynamics, resulting in two scalar nonets below @xmath13.
* The strong attractions between diquark states in relative @xmath16-wave may result in a nonet of tetraquark states below @xmath12.
* The tetraquark scenario can be used to study the nonet scalar mesons below @xmath12 as tetraquark states with QCD sum rules.
* The article constructs new QCD sum rules for the nonet scalar mesons using tetraquark currents with scalar diquark fields and new vacuum condensates.
</summary>

<summary>
* Power system dynamic analysis often uses time-domain simulation, but real systems have many components and time scales, making simulations expensive and challenging for online stability assessment.
* Two approaches to accelerate simulations are using larger time steps or implementing quasi-steady-state (QSS) models, but QSS models can have numerical difficulties and may not provide consistent approximations.
* This paper introduces the Pseudo-Transient Continuation (PTC) method, a theoretical-based numerical method for power system long-term stability analysis, which can be applied directly in the long-term stability model or the QSS model.
* PTC method follows the solution of dynamical systems accurately in early stages, then increases the time step to gain rapid convergence to steady state, making it a middle ground between accurate integration and direct steady-state calculation.
* For the long-term stability model, PTC method is modified to handle discrete variables and is implemented after the initial transient period. For the QSS model, PTC is used to overcome numerical difficulties starting from when short-term dynamics settle down.
* Numerical examples show that PTC method provides correct stability assessment and intermediate trajectories for the long-term stability model and overcomes numerical difficulties in the QSS model, offering a good alternative method for power system long-term stability analysis.
* The work was supported by the consortium for electric reliability technology solutions provided by the U.S. Department of Energy.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Background and Motivation:**
	+ Anisotropic quantum scattering in 2D has gained significant interest due to proposals for creating exotic quantum systems using dipolar gases and polar molecules.
	+ Recent experimental advancements in creating quasi-2D ultracold gases and producing polar molecules have opened up ways to realize these phenomena.
	+ The long-range and anisotropic nature of dipole-dipole interactions makes usual partial-wave analysis inefficient for describing 2D dipolar scattering.
* **Method Development:**
	+ The authors develop a method for quantitative analysis of 2D quantum scattering on long-range, strongly anisotropic scatterers.
	+ The method is based on the approach suggested in a previous work for few-dimensional scattering and successfully applied to 3D dipole-dipole scattering induced by an elliptically polarized laser field.
	+ The method uses an angular-grid representation of the wave function and reduces the 2D Schrödinger equation to a system of coupled ordinary differential equations.
* **Applications:**
	+ The method is applied to two problems: 2D scattering on a cylindrical potential with an elliptical base and 2D dipole-dipole scattering of unpolarized dipoles.
	+ For the cylindrical potential, the authors reproduce the threshold formula for the scattering amplitude with a circular base and validate their method by comparing with analytical results.
* **Convergence and Efficiency:**
	+ The method shows high efficiency in all problems considered, demonstrating rapid convergence with increasing angular grid points.
	+ For the 2D scattering on a potential barrier with circular base, the method converges to the analytical result as the barrier height increases and its width decreases.
* **Concluding Remarks:**
	+ The developed method provides a powerful tool for studying 2D quantum scattering on long-range, strongly anisotropic scatterers.
	+ The method's efficiency and accuracy make it suitable for investigating various 2D quantum systems, such as dipolar gases and polar molecules in optical traps.
</summary>

• **Historical Context**: G65.2+5.7, a supernova remnant (SNR), was initially studied in the 1980s and 1990s, with its radio and optical images and spectra recorded. However, it was later ignored until recently when it gained interest due to its potential in explaining thermal composite SNRs.
• **Thermal Composite SNRs**: These SNRs exhibit a combination of a shell-like radio continuum morphology and a centrally bright x-ray morphology, with x-ray emission due to thermal processes. Their origins are less understood compared to shell-type and plerionic SNRs.
• **G65.2+5.7's Characteristics**: Optical observations indicate that G65.2+5.7 has entered the shell formation phase, with a shell-like radio continuum morphology and thermal x-ray emission. However, it lacked the third requirement for thermal composite classification: a centrally filled x-ray morphology.
• **ROSAT Observations**: Archival ROSAT data revealed that G65.2+5.7 has a centrally filled x-ray morphology, with a temperature that peaks in the center and decreases mildly with radius. This confirms its classification as a thermal composite SNR.
• **Model Fits and Properties**: Model fits to the ROSAT data imply a temperature range of 2.5 to 3.4 keV, a column density range of 1.2 to 2.1 × 10^21 cm^-2, an apparent flux of 0.11 to 2.04 keV photons of 1.1 × 10^-11 ergs cm^-2 s^-1, and a luminosity of 1.2 × 10^36 ergs s^-1.
• **Implications and Future Work**: G65.2+5.7's classification as a thermal composite SNR supports the hypothesis that these SNRs are in the radiative phase of evolution. Further studies, such as targeted searches for CO emission features, could help understand the interaction between SNRs and molecular clouds.

<summary>
* **Permutations and Compression**: Permutations of integers are a fundamental building block for succinct encoding of various data types. The entropy of a permutation is a measure of its compressibility, with a lower bound of log(n) bits.
* **Sorting Algorithms and Entropy**: Adaptive sorting algorithms, such as merge sort, can take advantage of specificities in permutations to sort them more efficiently. The entropy of the partition of a permutation into sorted blocks is a useful measure of its compressibility.
* **Runs and Strict Runs**: Runs and strict runs are two types of contiguous subsequences in a permutation that can be used to compress it. The distribution of the sizes of the runs is a refinement of the number of runs that can be used to improve compression.
* **Shuffled Upsequences**: Shuffled upsequences are a more general type of subsequences that need not be contiguous. They can be used to compress permutations that have a small number of such subsequences.
* **Applications of Compressed Permutations**: Compressed permutations have various applications, such as encoding integer functions, text indexes, and binary relations. They can also be used to improve the efficiency of adaptive search algorithms.
* **Cycle Representation of Permutations**: A permutation can be represented as the concatenation of its cycles, completed by a bitvector coding the lengths of the cycles. This representation can be compressed using any of the permutation encodings described in the paper.
</summary>

<summary>
* A peculiar phenomenon called chimera states was discovered in populations of identical phase oscillators under nonlocal symmetric coupling.
* Chimera states are characterized by the coexistence of coherent (synchronized) and incoherent oscillators, resembling the mythological creature Chimera.
* The study of chimera states has since been extensive, with various models and experiments showing their occurrence, including coupled chemical oscillators and optical coupled-map lattices.
* In neuroscience, chimera states are believed to explain the phenomenon of unihemispheric sleep observed in birds and dolphins.
* This paper aims to identify chimera states in networks of non-locally coupled neurons represented by Hindmarsh-Rose oscillators.
* The authors use both 2D and 3D versions of the Hindmarsh-Rose model, with different coupling schemes, to observe various chimera states and a novel mixed oscillatory state (MOS).
* The study provides evidence for the relevance of chimera states in neuroscience applications and verifies their existence in coupled bistable elements.
</summary>

• **Kauffman Networks**: Kauffman networks are disordered dynamical systems proposed by Stuart Kauffman in 1969 as a model for genetic regulatory systems. They consist of a set of elements, each with a binary variable representing its state of activation, and each element is under the control of a certain number of other elements.
• **Dynamical Phase Transition**: Kauffman networks exhibit a dynamical phase transition, studied using mean field theory, where the average length of cycles increases exponentially with system size in the chaotic phase and does not increase with system size in the frozen phase. The phase transition is controlled by a parameter representing the probability that the responses to two different signals are different.
• **Stable and Relevant Elements**: Some elements in the network are stable, meaning they evolve to a constant state independent of the initial configuration. Other elements are relevant, meaning they can influence the long-time behavior of the system. The number of relevant elements determines the attractors of the network.
• **Annealed Approximation**: The annealed approximation, introduced by Derrida and Pomeau, is a method to study the properties of attractors in Kauffman networks. It is valid in the chaotic phase but fails on the critical line and in the frozen phase.
• **Relevant Elements and Attractors**: The number of relevant elements scales with system size in the different phases of the model. In the chaotic phase, it is expected to be linear in the system size, while in the frozen phase and on the critical line, it is expected to scale as a power law of the system size. The properties of the attractors can be directly drawn from the scaling of the number of relevant elements.

<summary>
* Turbulence is a strong nonequilibrium phenomenon in fluid systems, exhibiting unpredictable behavior of the velocity field, which can result from the multiple degrees of freedom and nonlinearity of the system.
* In quantum turbulence (qt), quantized vortices with quantized circulation are nucleated, forming tangles, which is different from classical turbulence (ct) where the circulation of the velocity field is not quantized.
* A new trend in turbulence study is the exploration of multi-component Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs), which exhibit novel turbulence with both velocity and spin fields disturbed and various topological excitations generated.
* The authors studied spin turbulence (st) in a spin-1 ferromagnetic spinor BEC, focusing on the spectrum of the spin-dependent interaction energy, and found a characteristic power law.
</summary>

• Low-luminosity active galactic nuclei (LLAGNs) are found in about 40% of nearby bright galaxies and are the majority of the AGN population.
• Their low luminosities are thought to be caused by very low accretion rates onto supermassive black holes, often explained by the advection-dominated accretion flow (ADAF) model.
• The ADAF model predicts a 'submillimetre bump' in the spectral energy distribution, while the standard disc is responsible for the 'big blue bump' in luminous AGNs.
• The first imaging investigations for accretion discs are promising with future very-long-baseline-interferometry (VLBI) instruments that will provide micro-arcsec resolutions.
• The authors conducted a millimetre survey and submillimetre data analyses for many LLAGNs to detect the inverted spectrum of the ADAF and avoid contamination from non-thermal jets and dust.

• The authors present three methods to measure the extinction law slope (Rv) in the direction of differentially reddened globular clusters using photometry.
• The first two methods rely on three-color optical photometry, while the third uses two-color optical photometry and a map of dust thermal emission.
• The methods are applied to the globular cluster NGC 4833, and the results are combined to estimate the extinction law slope in its direction.

<summary>
* The Kondo Lattice Model (KLM) was studied using Dynamical Cluster Approximation (DCA) with Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) solver, focusing on the ground state properties and fermi surface topology.
* The model was extended to allow for antiferromagnetic order, and the magnetic phase diagram was mapped out as a function of coupling strength and conduction electron density.
* The single-particle spectral function was calculated along high-symmetry paths in the extended Brillouin zone, revealing a change in fermi surface topology at small dopings away from half-filling.
* The absence of Kondo breakdown was confirmed throughout the phase diagram, and the transition from paramagnetic to antiferromagnetic state was found to be continuous, associated with backfolding of the large heavy fermion fermi surface.
</summary>

• The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) has discovered a resonance at 125 GeV, compatible with the Higgs boson, which is a significant step towards understanding the origin of the mass of fundamental particles.
• The Higgs field's non-minimal coupling to the curvature of spacetime, as invoked in various extensions of the Standard Model, may have the Higgs responsible for inflation and as a suppression mechanism for dark energy.
• Upper bounds on the gravitational interaction of Higgs bosons from LHC experiments have been discussed, and bounds on the coupling between the Higgs particle and gravity may also be obtained by considering strong-gravity astrophysical objects.
• The presence of a strong spacetime curvature deforms the vacuum expectation value of the Higgs field, leading to predicted wavelength shifts in electronic transitions that should be present in the spectra of white dwarfs, which have both atomic and molecular lines.

• White dwarf (WD) stars are the end result of stellar evolution for low-mass stars and make up over 97% of stars in our galaxy.
• Most WDs belong to the spectral class DA, with atmospheres dominated by hydrogen.
• When DA WDs cool to a certain temperature, they enter the ZZ Ceti (or DAV) instability strip, where global pulsations are driven and their fundamental parameters can be determined using asteroseismology.
• All DA WDs are believed to pass through the ZZ Ceti instability strip at some point and pulsate, although some may do so at low amplitudes.
• The instability strip runs in temperature from roughly 11,000 K for standard DA WDs and has a dependence on surface gravity.
• The blue edge of the instability strip has been successfully estimated, but the red edge remains a challenge to predict.
• The discovery of pulsating extremely low-mass (ELM) WDs provides an opportunity to study the physics of WD pulsations at cooler temperatures and lower masses.
• The authors discovered two new pulsating ELM WDs, bringing the total to five, and found that the coolest one, J2228, has a lower effective temperature than six similar-gravity ELMs that do not pulsate.

• The distribution of molecular hydrogen (H2) is similar across various local approximation models, with some overestimating or underestimating the H2 fraction compared to the fiducial model.
• The spatial distribution and amount of carbon monoxide (CO) show more sensitivity to the radiative shielding prescription, with some local models failing to produce significant CO.
• The mass-weighted fractional error metric (err) is used to quantify the agreement between local models and the fiducial model for both H2 and CO.
• The six-ray approximation (l6) has the smallest err for H2, followed by the temperature-capped jeans length (l1a) and density gradient (l3) models.
• For CO, model l1a has the lowest err, followed by the power-law fit (l4) and single-cell shielding (l5) models.
• The similarity between models l1a and l4 can be attributed to their respective density scalings, with both models performing well in predicting the abundances of H2 and CO.

• The text discusses a feature in the color-magnitude diagram (CMD) of the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) known as the vertical extension of the red clump (VRC).
• The VRC was first identified by Cannon in 1970 and is associated with the post-helium flash stage of stellar evolution.
• Zaritsky and Lin (ZL) proposed that the VRC is due to an intervening population of stars at 2 kpc, which may represent a dwarf galaxy or tidal debris sheared from a small Milky Way satellite.
• The Macho team found no evidence for a foreground population at 3 kpc in their extensive photometric database, confirming the LMC membership of their Cepheids.
• Gould argued that any luminous foreground population must not extend more than 5' from the LMC center, be smooth on 15' scales, have a stellar mass-to-light ratio 10 times that of known populations, or provide only a small fraction of the microlensing optical depth.
