• The department is currently working on developing guidance for participation in the information sharing environment to ensure adequate privacy protections.

• Social Security provides benefits to retirees, disabled workers, and dependents, with disabled workers and dependents potentially facing greater hardships.
• The program has expanded over time, with dependents' benefits added in 1939 and disability insurance in 1956.
• Social Security faces solvency challenges due to demographic changes, and reform proposals may affect disabled workers and dependents.

• <summary>
• The Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) was established in response to the 2008 financial crisis to stabilize the U.S. economy and financial system.
• TARP provided financial assistance to various sectors, including banks, automakers, and homeowners.
• As of September 30, 2014, Treasury had recovered $226.4 billion in repayments and income from its Capital Purchase Program (CPP) investments, exceeding the original amount disbursed by $21.5 billion.
• Treasury estimates that some nonhousing programs, such as the Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility (TALF) and the Public-Private Investment Program (PPIP), will produce lifetime income.
• Treasury has wound down four of nine nonhousing TARP programs and continues to exit others, such as the Community Development Capital Initiative (CDCI) and the Automotive Industry Financing Program (AIFP).
• Treasury has disbursed $13.7 billion (36 percent) of the $38.5 billion in TARP housing funds, with the Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP) being the largest recipient.
• </summary>

* <summary>
	+ The electricity sector is facing significant changes due to new regulations and market conditions, with power companies planning to retire more coal-fueled generating units than previously estimated.
	+ Retired units are generally older, smaller, more polluting, and less used, while retrofitted units are larger and geographically concentrated.
	+ DOE, EPA, and FERC have taken initial steps to monitor industry progress and coordinate efforts, but stakeholders continue to express concerns about reliability and electricity prices.
* </summary>

<summary>
• FSA did not consistently make annual eligibility determinations for estates kept open beyond 2 years, as required by regulations.
• Only 39 out of 181 estates received annual determinations, and many did not receive them every year.
• FSA did not conduct any determinations for 73 estates, including some that received large payments and had been open for over 10 years.
• Even when determinations were conducted, FSA sometimes approved eligibility with insufficient information or explanations.
• Some FSA field offices approved payments to groups of estates without any apparent determination.
• The extent to which FSA field offices make eligibility determinations varies from state to state.
• FSA cannot ensure that millions of dollars in farm program payments to deceased individuals from 1999 through 2005 were proper due to lack of management controls.
• FSA paid $1.1 billion in farm program payments to 172,801 deceased individuals, with 40% dead for 3 or more years and 19% dead for 7 or more years.
</summary>

<summary>
* FAA's ATC modernization program has experienced significant cost overruns, delays, and performance shortfalls over the past 16 years.
* The Advanced Automation System (AAS), the centerpiece of the modernization program, was restructured due to tripled costs and delayed implementation.
* FAA has spent over $25 billion on modernization projects, with $15.7 billion spent on ongoing projects and $5.3 billion on completed projects.
* Some equipment has been fielded, but delays in other projects have led to costly interim projects, and the agency continues to struggle with acquiring new systems within agreed-upon schedule and cost parameters.
* Two key components of the modernization effort, the Wide Area Augmentation System (WAAS) and the Standard Terminal Automation Replacement System (STARS), have encountered delays and cost increases.
* FAA faces challenges in addressing the year 2000 date requirements, with less than 2 years left to ensure critical systems are ready for reliable operation on January 1, 2000.
</summary>

<summary>
• The U.S. funded rule of law programs worldwide from 1993 to 1998, totaling at least $970 million.
• Annual funding increased from $128 million to $218 million over this period.
• Funding for Latin America and the Caribbean was the highest, at about 36%.
• Africa, Central Europe, and the former Soviet Union each received about 15%.
• Funding for Central Europe grew from $9 million to $67 million (31% of the total) by 1998.
• Latin America and the Caribbean funding declined from 44% to 19% over the same period.
• African funding also decreased from 30% to 13%.
• USAID had difficulties providing 1996 funding data due to system issues.
• The shift in funding was primarily from Latin America and the Caribbean to Central Europe.
• The total annual rule of law funding increased significantly from 1993 to 1998.
</summary>

• Franchise funds are government-run, self-supporting businesslike enterprises managed by federal employees.
• They provide a variety of common administrative services, such as payroll processing, information technology support, employee assistance programs, public relations, and contracting.
• Franchise funds are required to recover their full costs of doing business and are allowed to retain up to 4 percent of their total annual income.
• The Government Management Reform Act of 1994 authorized the Office of Management and Budget to designate six federal agencies to establish the franchise fund pilot program.

• Federal officials and stakeholders identified federal authorities, agency initiatives, joint community-level planning, leadership, community engagement, and agency resources for collaboration as directly affecting federal-nonfederal collaboration aimed at reducing wildland fire risk to communities.
• Many federal officials and stakeholders said an engaged community— that is, a community that understands the issues associated with wildland fire and is willing to take action to reduce risk—enhances federal- nonfederal collaboration to reduce wildland fire risk.
• Federal officials and stakeholders also identified factors that indirectly affect federal and nonfederal collaboration to reduce wildland fire risk in the WUI, including community education, fire prevention messaging, and state and local requirements for private property owners to take steps to reduce risk.
• Many federal officials and stakeholders said that improving implementation of the Cohesive Strategy, increasing collaborative planning, expanding education, increasing prevention efforts, and improving local timber-processing capabilities could improve federal agencies’ and nonfederal entities’ ability to reduce wildland fire risk to communities.
• Federal officials and stakeholders also identified actions that, while not necessarily within federal agencies’ control, could help reduce wildland fire risk to communities, including increasing state and local adoption of laws and ordinances that encourage fire-resistant building and the removal of potentially flammable vegetation and providing insurance incentives to encourage property owners and communities to adopt risk-reducing measures.
• Many federal officials and stakeholders said that improving the implementation of the Cohesive Strategy could help reduce wildland fire risk to communities.
• Many federal officials and stakeholders said increasing collaborative planning could help reduce wildland fire risk to communities.

• The Foundation received $3 million from the U.S. Treasury for the Memorial Garden in Normandy, with an additional $73,152 in interest earned by June 30, 1994.
• The Foundation's financial condition is precarious, with liabilities exceeding assets, and it's uncertain if it can meet its financial and operational responsibilities related to the Memorial Garden and other projects.

* Pension plans invest in hedge funds and private equity to achieve high returns and diversify portfolios.
* Hedge funds pose challenges such as reliance on manager skill, use of leverage, and high fees.
* Private equity funds require long-term commitments and uncertain valuation.
* Pension plans take steps to mitigate these challenges, such as due diligence and diversification.
* Survey data show that many plans invest in hedge funds and private equity.
* The majority of plans with hedge fund or private equity investments have small allocations.
* Larger plans are more likely to invest in hedge funds and private equity.
* State regulation of public pension plan investments varies.
* Labor and PBGC agree with the findings and recommend guidance for qualified plans under ERISA.

<summary>
• The U.S. territories of American Samoa, CNMI, Guam, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands have unique Medicaid and CHIP programs with different eligibility, benefits, and funding structures compared to states.
• Territories have some discretion in setting Medicaid and CHIP eligibility standards, provider payment rates, and benefits, but must follow federal guidelines.
• Federal funding for Medicaid and CHIP in territories is subject to caps, unlike in states, and territories must assume full costs once federal funding is exhausted.
• Territories' Medicaid and CHIP funding has increased temporarily due to legislation like the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 and the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA).
• Despite increased funding, territories may still face funding shortfalls and may need to restrict eligibility or reduce benefits once temporary funding expires.
• Territories' program integrity efforts are limited, with only Puerto Rico having a program integrity unit, and none having a Medicaid Fraud Control Unit (MFCU).
• Incomplete service-level expenditure reporting in territories hinders program integrity efforts and makes it difficult to identify potential fraud, waste, and abuse.
• CMS provides limited oversight and assistance to territories for program integrity, focusing mainly on technical assistance and resolving complaints.
</summary>

• **Potentially Eligible Sites for NPL**: 1,789 sites are potentially eligible for the National Priorities List (NPL), including 1,739 nonfederal sites and 50 federal facilities. These sites are located in 48 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the Northern Mariana Islands, and under the jurisdiction of the Navajo Nation.
• **Cleanup Actions and Risks**: Some cleanup activities have been conducted at 686 sites, while no substantive cleanup activities have been reported or no information is available for 1,103 sites. Officials responding to surveys estimated that 17% of the sites currently pose high human health and environmental risks, and another 10% potentially pose high future risks.

• State has taken temporary measures to address visa wait times, such as deploying temporary duty staff and repositioning consular staff, but these are not sustainable long-term solutions.
• State has not developed a comprehensive strategy to address increasing visa demand and has not estimated the resources needed to meet future demand, despite projecting significant growth in several countries.

• OPM's mission is to manage the federal government's civilian workforce, including retirement benefits.
• The agency administers two defined benefit retirement plans: CSRS and FERS.
• OPM's retirement processing is paper-based and manually intensive, leading to errors and delays.
• The agency has identified several factors limiting its ability to process retirement benefits efficiently and timely.
• OPM has a history of retirement modernization initiatives, with the most recent being RetireEZ.
• The RetireEZ program aimed to provide prompt and complete benefit payments upon retirement through an integrated system and automated processes.
• However, the program faced significant challenges and the DBTS contract was terminated in October 2008.
• OPM has not fully implemented the retirement modernization capabilities described in its 2007 plans.
• The agency has not developed a complete plan for its restructured RetireEZ program, including goals, measures, and a schedule.

<summary>
* The number of school-aged children with limited English proficiency in the U.S. has grown significantly over the last two decades.
* The Bilingual Education Act (BEA) was passed in 1968 to educate these students and meet their special needs.
* The 1994 reauthorization of BEA created four bilingual education grant programs to distribute funds directly to school districts serving children with limited English proficiency.
* Other federal programs, such as Title I, also address the needs of these children, but most services are funded with local and state dollars.
* Education's Office of Bilingual Education and Minority Languages Affairs (OBEMLA) administers the four competitive bilingual education grant programs.
* The four programs share similar performance goals, measures, and uses of funds, and target students with limited English proficiency in kindergarten through 12th grade.
* The legislative purpose and grant length of the four bilingual education programs vary, with PDI and Enhancement grants providing funding for 2 to 3 years, and Comprehensive and Systemwide grants providing funding for 5 years.
* Education officials believe that consolidating these programs has merit and have already taken steps to reduce overlap among the four programs.
* Federal cost savings from consolidating the four bilingual education programs would likely be small, but program consolidation may reduce applicant burden and allow Education to redirect resources to other activities.
* The Congress may want to consider consolidating the four bilingual education programs into one program with adequate flexibility to meet the varied needs of school districts serving students with limited English proficiency.
</summary>

• <summary>
  • NCIC is a nationwide criminal justice information system managed by the FBI, with over 92,000 law enforcement agencies accessing it.
  • The system includes approximately 35,000 federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies, with about 85,820 active missing persons records.
  • CJIS, along with state and local agencies, is responsible for ensuring compliance with NCIC policies, including the 2-hour entry requirement for missing children reports.
  • CJIS audits CSAs every 3 years to assess compliance with NCIC policies, including the 2-hour entry requirement, and provides recommendations for noncompliance.
  • During audits, CJIS reviews random samples of missing children records to determine compliance with the 2-hour entry requirement.
  • Of the 22 CSAs audited using the 2-hour criterion, 9 were found to be out of compliance, with the percentage of timely entries ranging from 53% to 91% across the 10 states.
  • CSA audits of LEAs vary in their approach to assessing timeliness and the number of missing children records reviewed, raising questions about the reliability of information on LEA compliance.
  </summary>

• Automobile crashworthiness is influenced by crash type, crash severity, automobile size, safety belt use, and driver age and gender.
• Crash type and crash severity are the most important factors affecting driver injury, followed by safety belt use, driver age and gender, and automobile size.
• Women drivers are more likely to be hospitalized or killed in collisions with cars and light trucks than in one-car crashes, while older drivers have a greater risk of injury in both one-car and multivehicle crashes.
• Safety belts may not protect women drivers as well as men drivers, and the effectiveness of safety belts is roughly equivalent for drivers 16 to 64 and for drivers 65 and older.
• To improve automobile safety, efforts should focus on reducing crash involvement for men drivers and younger drivers, and improving crashworthiness for women and older drivers.

* The Coast Guard's budget request for fiscal year 2008 is $8.73 billion, an increase of 3.3% from the previous year.
* The budget includes $5.9 billion for operating expenditures, which supports the agency's 11 mission programs, as well as increases in cost of living, fuel, and maintenance costs.
* The budget also includes $2.83 billion for capital expenditures, with a significant portion of this funding allocated to the Coast Guard's Deepwater program.

• DOD's Families First program aims to improve the quality of household goods moves for servicemembers and civilians by using performance-based service contracts, streamlining claims, and providing expanded counseling services.
• The program has faced delays and missed milestones in developing and implementing the Defense Personal Property System (DPS), which is intended to support these goals.
• DOD has taken some initial steps to achieve the program's goals, such as implementing electronic billing and payment systems and a customer satisfaction survey.
• However, the program's implementation is at risk due to organizational changes, staffing shortfalls, and lack of stakeholder agreement on key elements.
• DOD has not employed comprehensive planning to manage program implementation, and the program's offices are facing challenges in hiring and retaining qualified personnel.
• The program's cost is projected to increase by about $1.4 billion over current program costs through fiscal year 2011, with DPS alone expected to cost about $180 million through fiscal year 2011.
• DOD has not set aside funding to fully cover these costs, and the services vary in how they have budgeted for the increased costs expected to implement the Families First program.

• The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulates pesticides used on tobacco in the United States, including assessing their health risks and setting residue limits for food and feed crops.
• EPA does not set residue limits for pesticides approved for use on tobacco, as it is not used as food or feed.
• USDA tests imported and domestic tobacco for residues of 20 pesticides not approved for use in the United States, primarily for purposes of trade equity.
• The USDA testing program found less than 1 percent of domestically produced or imported flue-cured and burley tobacco with residue levels above the allowable limits from 1999 to 2001.
• Germany, Italy, and Spain have residue limits on tobacco for 20, 24, and 21 of the 37 pesticides commonly used on U.S. tobacco during the 1990s, respectively.
• The North Carolina State University (NCSU) collected data on the residues of various pesticides on some domestically grown tobacco in the 1990s, with residue levels varying for different pesticides.

• User fees are a way to finance federal programs or activities, with users paying for services above and beyond what is normally available to the general public.
• User fees can promote equity by assigning costs to those who benefit from the service, and economic efficiency by encouraging users to make decisions based on costs and benefits.
• User fees can also raise equity and efficiency concerns, as they may shift the burden to those less able to pay and create competitive advantages or disadvantages.
• Fees should be set and adjusted to cover the intended share of program costs over time, and regular reviews and updates are necessary to ensure they remain aligned with program costs.
• The beneficiary-pays principle guides the extent to which a program should be funded by user fees versus general revenues, based on who primarily benefits from the program.
• User fees can be practical, equitable, and efficient only when users can be identified and charged for the service, and fee collections are sufficient to cover the intended share of program costs.
• The boundaries between fees and taxes are not always clear, and the trade-offs among design elements presented in this guide can be relevant to both.
• In theory, the extent to which a program is funded by user fees should generally be guided by who primarily benefits from the program, but the extent to which a program benefits users or the general public is not usually clear cut.
• Fees should be set and adjusted to cover the intended share of costs over time, which means agencies must project and consider future program costs.
• The primary challenge in determining when and how to collect a fee is striking a balance between ensuring compliance and minimizing administrative costs.
* <summary>OSSE and DCPS have used federal payments for various school improvement activities, including facility renovation, summer school programs, and professional development.</summary>

• **Agency Budgets and Strategic Goals**: Agencies may not fully link their budgets to strategic goals, leading to misaligned resource allocation. They often pursue individual needs rather than collective ones, and congressional directives may require purchases that are not planned or needed.
• **Requirements Instability and Overpromising**: Programs often face requirements instability, causing delays, cost growth, and reduced end items. Agencies may overpromise on capabilities, costs, and schedules, leading to underdelivery.
• **Contract Management Challenges**: Contracts may lack definitive requirements, accurately reflect project complexity, or appropriately allocate risk. Incentive and award fees may not be tied to positive results, and key program staff may rotate too frequently.
• **Acquisition Workforce Challenges**: The acquisition workforce faces size, skills, and knowledge challenges, as well as succession planning issues. The revolving door between industry and government may present conflicts of interest.
• **Lack of Oversight and Accountability**: Inadequate oversight results in little or no accountability for recurring and systemic problems. Lack of high-level attention reduces the chances of success in acquisition, contracting, and other key business areas.
• **Contracting Out and Workforce Size**: Agencies may rely too heavily on contractors, increasing the need for oversight. The acquisition workforce's size has decreased while its workload and complexity have increased, presenting significant challenges.
• **Strategic Human Capital Planning**: Agencies need to engage in strategic human capital planning to develop long-term strategies for acquiring, developing, motivating, and retaining staff to achieve programmatic goals. They should also engage in succession planning and management efforts to strengthen their current and future organizational capacity.

<summary>
* DOD sets a standard price for fuel annually, based on crude oil price, refinement markup, and nonproduct costs.
* The crude oil price is forecasted by the Troika and provided by OMB, with DOD using the WTI projection as its baseline.
* DOD adds a markup for refinement costs, estimated based on the historical price relationship between WTI crude oil and refined product prices.
* Nonproduct costs include overhead, transportation, storage, and other related expenses.
* DOD's actual fuel costs have differed significantly from estimated costs in recent years, primarily due to fluctuations in fuel prices and differences in consumption estimates.
* DOD has taken actions to manage fluctuations in the cash balance of the Defense-wide Working Capital Fund, including transfers and adjustments to the standard price.
* DOD has studied various aspects of its bulk fuel program since 2004, but has not updated its approach for setting the standard price to reflect current market conditions or documented its rationale for assumptions.
* DOD's current approach for establishing the standard price has not accounted for changes in market conditions for crude oil, such as the decreasing relationship between crude oil and refined prices.
</summary>

* <summary>
	+ The Department of Defense (DOD) initiated the Standard Procurement System (SPS) program in 1994 to acquire and deploy a single automated system for managing contracts and contract-related documents.
	+ The program has faced numerous challenges, including delays, cost overruns, and user dissatisfaction, as highlighted in several reports by the DOD Office of the Inspector General (OIG) and the Government Accountability Office (GAO).
	+ DOD has not met key commitments for SPS, including the full operational capability milestone, user satisfaction, and the use of a commercial system solution.
	+ The program has experienced significant cost increases, with total actual program costs not being accumulated and monitored against estimates.
	+ DOD has not economically justified investing in SPS, as its own analysis shows that expected life-cycle benefits are less than estimated life-cycle costs.
	+ The GAO recommends that the Secretary of Defense direct the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Command, Control, Communications, and Intelligence (C3I) to clarify organizational accountability and responsibility for measuring SPS progress against commitments and to ensure that these responsibilities are met.
	+ The GAO also recommends that the Secretary direct the C3I to make investment in each new release or enhancement to SPS conditional upon validating that already implemented releases of the system are producing benefits that exceed costs and demonstrating that proposed new releases or enhancements will produce benefits that exceed costs.
* </summary>

* <summary>
* USCIS is responsible for processing millions of immigration benefit applications each year.
* USCIS has a staff of about 3,000 permanent adjudicators located in 4 service centers and 33 district offices.
* USCIS processes applications for about 50 types of immigration benefits.
* In fiscal year 2005, USCIS received about 6.3 million applications and adjudicated about 7.5 million applications.
* USCIS has a backlog of several million applications and has developed a plan to eliminate it by the end of fiscal year 2006.
* USCIS has established the Office of Fraud Detection and National Security (FDNS) to enhance its fraud control efforts.
* FDNS has outlined a strategy for detecting immigration benefit fraud in USCIS’s National Benefit Fraud Strategy.
* FDNS has established Fraud Detection Units (FDU) in each of the service centers and appointed Immigration Officers to work directly with adjudicators.
* FDNS has initiated a fraud assessment program to determine the extent and nature of fraud for several immigration benefits.
* USCIS has not yet implemented some aspects of internal control standards and fraud control best practices that could further enhance its ability to detect fraud.
* USCIS has not applied a comprehensive risk management approach to help guide its fraud control efforts.
* USCIS has not established a mechanism to help ensure that knowledge arising from routine operations informs the assessment of policies and procedures.
* USCIS has not clearly communicated the importance of balancing multiple agency objectives.
* USCIS does not have a mechanism to help ensure that adjudicators have access to important information.
* USCIS does not have performance goals related to fraud prevention.
* DHS has not developed a strategy for imposing sanctions or evaluating their effectiveness.
* DHS has proposed administrative rule changes that will help sanction those who commit fraud.
* We recommend that DHS take several actions to enhance USCIS’s overall immigration benefit fraud control environment.
* DHS agreed with and plans to take action to implement four of our six recommendations.
* DHS cited actions it has already taken to indicate that aspects of our other two recommendations are already in place.
* DHS agreed that USCIS can enhance its risk management approach by expanding its fraud assessment program to cover more application types.
* DHS stated that it needs to provide USCIS staff access to relevant internal and external information and is initiating training for supervisory adjudication officers.
* DHS agreed that additional output and outcome based performance goals and

• **Filing Season Performance**: IRS processed 113.4 million individual income tax returns in 1994, slightly below expectations due to a drop in filers in 1993.
• **Alternative Filing Methods**: Electronic filing and TeleFile use increased, while 1040PC use declined due to software delays and user issues.
• **Computer Systems**: IRS' computer systems performed well, with minimal downtime and no major delays in refunds.
• **Refund Accuracy and Timeliness**: IRS met its goals for refund accuracy (98.6%) and timeliness (36 days on average).
• **Lockboxes and Deposits**: IRS tested lockbox systems and required service centers to expedite tax payment deposits, with positive results.
• **Returns Processing Accuracy**: IRS exceeded its accuracy goals for returns processing (95.3% for Code and Edit, 95.8% for Transcription).
• **Earned Income Credit (EIC) Errors**: EIC-related errors remained high, with staff overlooking missing Schedule EICs in some cases.
• **Refund Fraud**: IRS identified 58,828 fraudulent refund claims, twice as many as in the first half of 1993, with almost all involving EIC claims.
• **Telephone Assistance**: Taxpayers experienced difficulty reaching IRS by phone, with accessibility rates decreasing and demand increasing.

* TennCare is a capitated managed care program in Tennessee that expanded health coverage to hundreds of thousands of uninsured people.
* The program was implemented rapidly, leading to confusion among enrollees, providers, and MCOs.
* TennCare's capitation rates were set using historical Medicaid costs and were reduced by charity care deductions and enrollee cost sharing.
* Consultants found that the capitation rates were actuarially unsound and needed to be increased by 20 percent.
* The financial performance of MCOs was weak in the first year, with BlueCross BlueShield reporting a loss of $8.8 million.
* Access MedPLUS, the second largest MCO, had financial reporting problems and may not be viable.
* The state's lack of experience with managed care led to start-up problems, including confusion, provider resistance, and delays in enrollment and claims processing.
* TennCare's rapid implementation and lack of managed care experience led to several problems, such as confusion among enrollees, providers, and MCOs.
* The state's hotline averaged 50,000 calls a day after program start-up, compared with 9,000 calls a day in the following quarter.
* The state reported general start-up problems for MCOs, such as inability to handle the large volume of enrollee calls, adjusting to the increased enrollment, and claims processing problems.

• The federal government has made changes to improve drug detection mechanisms and response to emerging drug use problems.
• However, there is still a need for a defined strategy to determine the timing, nature, and magnitude of responses to new drug use patterns.

• **State Profiling Methods**: States use statistical models or characteristic screens to identify claimants likely to exhaust benefits. Most states use statistical models, with 45 out of 53 using them, while 7 use screens and 1 delegates the choice to local areas.
• **Model Variables and Updates**: States consider various factors in their models, with 34 using additional variables beyond those recommended by Labor. Many states have not updated their models in recent years, with 18 not doing so since 1999 or before.
• **Reemployment Services**: States provide reemployment services to profiled claimants, with an average of 15 percent referred and 11 percent completing services. Services vary, with some states requiring assessments and service plans, while others do not.

* The military health system has three missions: maintaining the health of active-duty service members, maintaining readiness, and providing care to dependents and retirees.
* The Medicare subvention demonstration allowed DOD to create managed care organizations for older retirees, with Medicare paying DOD for enrollees' care after DOD spent an amount equal to its historical spending on care for all older retirees.

<summary>
* NTSB has fully implemented or made significant progress in following leading management practices in eight areas.
* The agency has fully implemented three recommendations and made further progress on eight others since 2008.
* NTSB has taken steps to improve communication, strategic planning, IT, knowledge management, organizational structure, human capital management, training, and financial management.
* The agency has not yet fully implemented four recommendations but has initiated actions that could lead to their full implementation.
* NTSB's current workforce demographics present an opportunity to increase the diversity of its workforce and management.
</summary>

<summary>
* **EPA's Performance in Key Outcomes**: EPA reported progress in improving air quality, reducing toxic emissions, and ensuring safe drinking water. However, data limitations and reporting lags exist for some outcomes.
* **Strategies for Achieving Outcomes**: EPA's strategies include working with states, tribes, and local governments, implementing regulatory approaches, and providing funding and technical assistance to states.
* **Weaknesses and Opportunities**: EPA's strategies could be implemented more effectively by improving planning for research, addressing state spending constraints, and enhancing source water assessments.
* **Improvements in Performance Reporting**: EPA's fiscal year 2000 report showed improvements in discussing prior year performance, actions by other organizations, and data quality. The report was also easily comparable to the fiscal year 2002 performance plan.
* **Changes in Performance Plan**: EPA's fiscal year 2002 performance plan had numerous changes to goals and objectives, but did not explain the reasons for these changes. It also fell short in providing specifics on crosscutting goals and measures.
* **Addressing Major Management Challenges**: EPA's performance report discussed progress in resolving human capital, information security, and EPA-state working relationships challenges. The performance plan had goals and measures related to these challenges, except for EPA-state working relationships.
</summary>

<summary>
* **CIM Initiative Overview**: The Department of Defense (DOD) launched the Corporate Information Management (CIM) initiative in 1989 to improve business practices, make better use of information technology, and eliminate duplicative information systems across seven administrative areas. The primary objective of CIM is to significantly improve business processes of all functional areas through techniques such as business process reengineering and continuous process improvements.
* **CIM Implementation Strategy**: DOD initially focused on eliminating separate service systems and providing integrated systems across DOD. However, the CIM scope broadened to include all DOD functional areas, and its primary objective shifted to significantly improving business processes through techniques such as business process reengineering and continuous process improvements. DOD believes that this top-down review offers the best opportunity for innovative improvements that have the greatest potential for significant cost savings.
* **CIM Migration Strategy**: In November 1992, DOD shifted CIM's implementation emphasis back to information systems. The Deputy Secretary of Defense directed that senior DOD managers accelerate the selection and deployment of migration systems. DOD believes that selecting a common set of information systems is necessary to make functional integration and interoperability possible so that all DOD activities can work together more efficiently and effectively. However, some experts advise DOD to focus its efforts on reengineering its business processes before improving the automated information systems supporting these processes.
* **JLSC's Role**: The Joint Logistics Systems Center (JLSC) was established to achieve CIM goals for the materiel management and depot maintenance business areas. JLSC's charter is to work with the services and DLA to identify business process improvements and the appropriate application of information systems. Under this concept, JLSC serves primarily as a facilitator; the services and DLA design, develop, integrate, and implement the new corporate logistics systems.
* **CIM Impediments and Recommendations**: Three critical impediments are jeopardizing JLSC’s ability to successfully implement its strategy for improving business practices: lack of full acceptance of CIM by functional and technical managers, lack of integration of CIM efforts across DOD, and unclear program management authority. To overcome these impediments, the Secretary of Defense should revise the CIM management strategy to ensure active participation of functional managers, train DOD employees to promote understanding and acceptance of changes, and change the name of the CIM initiative to lessen confusion and more accurately communicate its primary objective.
</summary>

<summary>
• GAO investigators produced counterfeit NRC documents and a bill of lading for an undercover operation.
• They transported radioactive sources sufficient to make a dirty bomb across the U.S.-Canada and U.S.-Mexico borders.
• At the Canadian border, CBP inspectors did not question the counterfeit documents and allowed entry.
• At the Mexican border, CBP inspectors verified the presence of radioactive sources but did not question the counterfeit documents.
• GAO briefed CBP and NRC officials about the results of the border crossing tests.
• CBP agreed to work with NRC to verify the authenticity of NRC documents.
• NRC officials disagreed with GAO's estimate of the amount of radioactive material needed for a dirty bomb.
• GAO believes that counterfeiting NRC documents and purchasing radioactive sources are serious issues that NRC should address.
</summary>

• **DOD's Technology Transition Programs**: DOD has established several programs to transition technologies from labs to acquisitions, including ACTD, FCT, MANTECH, Dual Use, TTI, DACP, and Quick Reaction Fund.
• **Purpose and Funding**: These programs aim to speed up technology transition, save costs, and improve military operations. TTI, DACP, and Quick Reaction Fund received about $64 million in fiscal year 2005.
• **Challenges and Benefits**: Challenges include demonstrating potential, acquiring program willingness, and budgeting. Benefits include performance improvements, affordability, manufacturability, and operational capability.
• **TTI, DACP, and Quick Reaction Fund**: These three programs have reported benefits, but it's too early to assess their overall impact. TTI and DACP have completed 20 projects, with 13 available to warfighters.
• **Selection and Management**: Effective selection, management, and oversight processes are crucial for successful technology transition. DARPA and ACTD use tools like deal brokers and agreements.
• **DACP's Selection Process**: DACP uses internet-based tools, expert assessments, and acquisition program manager commitments. TTI has specific criteria and a council of DOD S&T officials. Quick Reaction Fund selects projects quickly for immediate use in military operations.
• **Performance Measures**: DOD should develop data and measures to assess program performance and return on investment. FCT and ACTD studies could serve as starting points.

• The Master Address File (MAF) is a crucial data file used by the U.S. Census Bureau for decennial censuses and other demographic surveys.
• The Bureau aims to improve the MAF's accuracy, continuous updates, and cost-effectiveness for the 2020 Census.
• The Bureau is researching targeted address canvassing to update the MAF more cost-effectively.
• The Bureau's 2020 Census preparation life cycle includes five phases, with early research and testing planned through fiscal year 2015.
• The Bureau's schedules for MAF development efforts, GSS-I and 2020 Research and Testing, exhibit some characteristics of reliable schedules but have significant weaknesses.
• The schedules lack comprehensiveness, well-constructed logic, and credibility, which could hinder management's ability to assess progress, make decisions, and identify risks.
• The Bureau has not yet conducted a quantitative risk analysis on its schedules, which could help predict the likelihood of meeting project completion dates.
• The Bureau has implemented a change control process for its schedules and provides regular updates to management.
• The Bureau has not yet provided training in scheduling software to its staff, which could impact the reliability of the schedules.

• The Clean Air Act, passed in 1963 and significantly amended in 1970 and 1990, regulates air pollution from stationary and mobile sources.
• EPA is responsible for setting national ambient air quality standards (NAAQS) for six major pollutants and reviewing them every 5 years.
• EPA has completed most of the 452 actions required by the 1990 amendments related to Titles I, III, and IV, but many were met late.
• EPA missed deadlines due to factors such as prioritizing actions, stakeholder involvement, and litigation.
• Despite progress, large numbers of Americans continue to live in areas with unhealthy air pollution levels.
• EPA's workload may increase due to recommendations for regulatory reform and ongoing air pollution problems.

<summary>
* OJJDP established the Girls Study Group in 2004 to identify effective programs for preventing and reducing girls' delinquency.
* The group reviewed over 1,000 documents and identified 61 programs targeting girls' delinquency.
* The group assessed the methodological quality of studies on these programs using OJP's What Works criteria.
* The group found that few programs had been studied and that available studies lacked conclusive evidence of effectiveness.
* OJJDP plans to provide technical assistance and issue a solicitation for evaluations of girls' delinquency programs, but has not yet developed a comprehensive plan for meeting its goals.
</summary>

<summary>
* **DFAS and Military Services Finance and Accounting Organization**: DFAS and military services share finance and accounting responsibilities, with DFAS reporting to the Under Secretary of Defense Comptroller/Chief Financial Officer and military services reporting to their respective secretaries. DFAS and military services have negotiated responsibility matrices for specific activities. DFAS and military services have separate chains of command, with DFAS reporting directly to the Under Secretary and military services reporting to their respective secretaries.
* **DFAS and Military Services Finance and Accounting Personnel**: DFAS has 23,500 employees, while military services estimate they have 17,300 personnel performing finance and accounting activities. DFAS and military services have different approaches to managing their finance and accounting workforce. DFAS tracks its personnel, while military services do not centrally budget for or manage finance and accounting operations.
* **DFAS and Military Services Finance and Accounting Budgets**: DFAS' 1996 budget was $1.64 billion, with plans to decrease by 10 percent by 2000. Military services estimate their personnel costs for fiscal year 1996 at $598 million. DFAS bills customers for full cost of operations, with military services paying from operations and maintenance appropriations.
* **DFAS and Military Services Finance and Accounting Systems**: DFAS is responsible for reducing the number of finance and accounting systems used throughout DOD. As of September 30, 1996, DFAS had reduced the number of finance systems from 127 to 67 and accounting systems from 197 to 150. Military services continue to operate hundreds of feeder systems for which DFAS has no responsibility.
</summary>

• The Federal Reserve System's structure, including the Reserve Banks' stock purchase requirement and 6 percent dividend, was designed to balance power between commercial banks and government, and to provide nationwide input for monetary policies.
• The Fixing America's Surface Transportation Act (FAST Act) modified the Reserve Banks' stock dividend rate and capped their aggregate surplus account, which could potentially affect the Federal Reserve's financial independence and autonomy in monetary policy decision making.

<summary>
* The 1992 Act established a task force to study motor vehicle titling, registration, and salvage issues, which recommended uniform definitions, titling and control methods, duplicate title issuance, national inspections, exportation of vehicles, funding, and enforcement.
* The 1992 Act also required the establishment of the National Stolen Passenger Motor Vehicle Information System (NSPMVIS) to track stolen vehicles and parts, with the National Insurance Crime Bureau (NICB) serving as the system administrator.
* The implementation of these provisions has been slowed by issues such as lack of federal funding, state participation, and technological challenges, as well as concerns about the size and scope of the pilot study for the titling system and the need for immunity for participants acting in good faith.
</summary>

* **Entities Involved**: The distribution and payment for prescription drugs involves interactions among drug wholesalers, independent pharmacies, PSAOs (Pharmacy Services Administrative Organizations), and third-party payers/PBMs (Pharmacy Benefit Managers).
* **PSAO Role**: PSAOs negotiate contracts with third-party payers/PBMs on behalf of independent pharmacies, provide communication and help-desk services, and offer other administrative support to create efficiencies for both pharmacies and payers/PBMs.
* **PSAO Ownership**: Most PSAOs are owned by wholesalers or independent pharmacy cooperatives, with some requiring member pharmacies to also use services from their non-PSAO lines of business.

• The report assesses the status of federal department and agency enterprise architecture efforts.
• The report focuses on 28 enterprise architecture programs relating to 27 major departments and agencies.
• The report uses a data collection instrument based on GAO's Enterprise Architecture Management Maturity Framework (EAMMF) and related guidance.
• The report analyzes the extent to which each department and agency satisfies the 31 core elements in the EAMMF.
• The report also solicits information on enterprise architecture challenges, benefits, costs, tools, and frameworks.
• The report finds wide variability in department and agency costs to develop and maintain their enterprise architectures.
• The report finds that most departments and agencies have not fully satisfied all the core elements needed to be at stage 2 or above in the EAMMF.
• The report finds that most departments and agencies are not yet where they need to be relative to architecture content, use, and measurement.
• The report finds that the key to realizing the potential benefits of enterprise architectures is effectively managing department and agency enterprise architecture programs.
• The report recommends that the Administrators of the Environmental Protection Agency, General Services Administration, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Small Business Administration, and U.S. Agency for International Development; the Attorney General; the Commissioners of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and Social Security Administration; the Directors of the National Science Foundation and the Office of Personnel Management; and the Secretaries of the Departments of Agriculture, Commerce, Defense, Education, Energy, Health and Human Services, Homeland Security, Housing and Urban Development, Interior, Labor, State, Transportation, Treasury, and Veterans Affairs ensure that their respective enterprise architecture programs develop and implement plans for fully satisfying each of the conditions in the EAMMF.

* The U.S. free trade agreement (FTA) with Oman was concluded in 2005 and signed in 2006, aiming to boost economic growth, create jobs, and support peace and stability in the Middle East.
* The agreement eliminates tariffs on U.S. exports to Oman, provides market access for U.S. services and investors, and includes enforceable labor and environmental provisions.

• Hate crimes are criminal offenses motivated by bias against a person's race, religion, disability, ethnic/national origin, or sexual orientation.
• Congress has recognized the concerns and effects of hate crimes through various laws.
• The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act expanded the scope of hate crime victims and federal jurisdiction.
• The commerce clause, 14th Amendment, and 13th/15th Amendments are potential authorities for hate crime legislation.
• Morrison v. United States narrowed Congress's authority under the commerce clause to regulate violent criminal conduct.
• The 14th Amendment's section 5 may not cover hate crimes by private individuals not acting under color of law.
• The 13th Amendment's section 2 may provide broader authority, but its application to non-race/color victims is unclear.
• The 1st Amendment protects freedom of speech and may limit hate crime legislation targeting speech or expression.
• The 6th Amendment guarantees a jury trial and may limit hate crime sentencing enhancements.

<summary>
* The exchange rate policies of some East Asian nations, particularly China, Japan, and South Korea, have been a source of tension with the United States.
* Some argue that these countries intentionally keep their currencies undervalued to gain a competitive advantage in global markets, which may violate IMF rules.
* The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 requires the U.S. Treasury to analyze exchange rates and policies of major trading partners.
* In its April 2017 report, the Treasury found no major trading partner met all three criteria for currency manipulation, but placed six on a "Monitoring List," including China, Japan, and South Korea.
* East Asian governments prefer "managed float" exchange rate policies, as they believe it's more conducive to their economic goals and objectives.
* Some East Asian governments may be resistant to a "free float" policy due to the perceived negative impact of the 1997-1998 Asian financial crisis on economies with more liberal exchange rate policies.
* There's no consensus among economists that adopting "free float" policies by more East Asian countries would significantly reduce U.S. trade deficits.
* The debate over foreign exchange rate policies and their impact on the U.S. economy continues in the 115th Congress, with bills like the Currency Reform for Fair Trade Act proposing countervailing duties on imports from countries with undervalued currencies.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Role and Authority of U.S. Ambassadors (Chiefs of Mission):** U.S. ambassadors, as Chiefs of Mission (COMs), serve as the President's personal representatives abroad, leading diplomatic efforts and overseeing nearly all U.S. government activities in their country of assignment. Their primary responsibilities include promoting U.S. goods and services, coordinating and supervising activities of executive branch agencies, and ensuring the security of U.S. government personnel. COM authority extends to all executive branch personnel, except those under the command of a Geographic Combatant Commander (GCC) and Voice of America (VOA) correspondents.
* **COM Authority in Practice:** COM authority is not always effectively exercised due to various factors, including lack of support from the State Department, agency interests, and insufficient training. Some analysts suggest that COMs may not receive adequate backing from the State Department to protect their authority, and that interagency experience and standardized training could improve COM effectiveness.
* **Improving COM Performance:** Several proposals have been made to enhance the exercise of COM authority, such as selecting potential COMs with interagency experience, expertise, and inclination, and standardizing their education and training. The State Department has taken steps to improve COM training, but some analysts question whether these measures will be sufficient without strong support from the State Department and recognition of the COM's role within the agency and among other agencies.
</summary>

• **Economic Dependence**: China's economy heavily relies on global trade and investment flows, with exports contributing significantly to its GDP growth. The global economic slowdown has negatively impacted China's export sector and industries dependent on foreign direct investment (FDI).
• **Financial Exposure**: China's exposure to the U.S. sub-prime mortgage crisis is unclear, but its large foreign exchange reserves, invested mainly in U.S. securities, could be at risk if the dollar depreciates. Chinese officials have expressed concerns about the safety of their U.S. investments.
• **Government Response**: The Chinese government has implemented a two-year, 4 trillion yuan ($586 billion) stimulus package to boost the economy, focusing on infrastructure projects, affordable housing, and rural development. It has also announced plans to create a universal health care system and boost rural incomes.
• **U.S.-China Economic Ties**: The global financial crisis has affected U.S.-China economic relations, with China blaming U.S. economic policies for the crisis and implementing measures that could increase trade tensions. Despite this, both countries have pledged to work together to support global trade and investment flows and resist protectionism.

• **Leasing and Permitting Process**: The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) and the Forest Service manage oil and gas development on federal public domain lands. BLM manages most of these lands, while the Forest Service manages National Forest System (NFS) lands. Leasing involves competitive and noncompetitive bidding, with the Secretary of the Interior (or the Secretary of Agriculture for NFS lands) having the authority to withdraw lands from leasing. Permitting requires an Application for a Permit to Drill (APD) and a surface use plan of operations, with BLM and the Forest Service making decisions based on environmental assessments or impact statements.
• **Legal Framework**: The Mineral Lands Leasing Act of 1920 (MLLA) authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to lease oil and gas deposits on public domain lands, with the federal government retaining title. The Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (FLPMA) requires the Secretary to develop land use plans (Resource Management Plans, or RMPs) that consider multiple use and sustained yield principles. The National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (NEPA) requires federal agencies to assess the environmental impacts of their actions.
• **Energy Policy Act of 2005**: The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (2005 EPACT) made several changes to federal oil and gas leasing laws. It required the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture to enter into a memorandum of understanding to streamline processing of lease applications and surface use plans. The 2005 EPACT also established a rebuttable presumption that categorical exclusions under NEPA would apply to certain actions taken under MLLA for oil and gas exploration or development.

• In 2014, 30% of U.S. tax filers chose to itemize deductions, with higher-income individuals more likely to do so.
• The average sum of itemized deductions claimed increased with income, ranging from $15,857 for those with less than $20,000 AGI to $424,864 for those with over $1 million AGI.
• The majority of itemizers (56.2%) had incomes less than $100,000, but they claimed only 36.4% of total itemized deductions.
• The home mortgage interest deduction was the largest single deduction for most income groups, while the deduction for state and local income taxes was largest for those with AGI over $500,000.
• The charitable gifts deduction increased sharply for those with AGI over $1 million, averaging $172,529.
• Limiting itemized deductions could increase revenue, but may also affect tax filer behavior and the progressivity of the tax code.

* The Pacific Islands region faces environmental challenges such as climate change, ocean acidification, and illegal fishing, which threaten its ecosystems and economies.
* The region is strategically important to the United States, with friendly relations and shared interests with Pacific Island countries, and is also a focus of engagement by other major powers such as China.

<summary>
* The Endangered Species Act (ESA) provides for the listing and protection of species that are endangered or threatened with extinction.
* Federal agencies are required to consult with the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) or the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) to determine if their actions might jeopardize listed species or destroy their critical habitat.
* If a project could jeopardize a species, a jeopardy opinion is released along with reasonable and prudent alternatives (RPAs) to avoid jeopardy.
* To excuse incidental taking of listed species, the Services issue an incidental take statement that includes reasonable and prudent measures (RPMs) to minimize the effects of the project.
* If a federal action cannot be conducted without jeopardizing species, and the federal agency believes that the RPAs would thwart the project, the exemption process can be initiated.
* The exemption process offers the opportunity to consider extraordinary economic circumstances in the list of factors used in evaluating federal actions.
* The Endangered Species Committee (ESC) reviews applications for exemptions and is responsible for the ultimate decision.
* An exemption is for a federal project, license, or action, rather than for a species, and the ESA still requires that species affected by the exempted project must be conserved in their remaining habitat.
* There have been only six instances in which an exemption was sought, and only two in which it was granted.
* The exemption process is complex and time-consuming, and potential applicants must balance the costs of the process with the benefits of winning an exemption.
</summary>

<summary>
* The federal individual income tax treats capital gains and losses in a specific way.
* Capital gains are taxed at a maximum rate of 15% for long-term assets held over a year.
* Capital losses can be deducted against gains or up to $3,000 of ordinary income.
* The tax treatment of capital gains and losses has changed repeatedly over the years.
* Some changes aimed to reestablish symmetry between the tax treatment of gains and losses.
* Currently, net long-term losses can be deducted against net short-term gains without limit.
* This rule creates inconsistencies due to different tax rates for gains and losses.
* The loss limitation was enacted because taxpayers control the timing of gains and losses.
* Increasing the loss limitation could increase the dichotomy between tax treatment of gains and losses.
</summary>

<summary>
* The National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) recognizes employees' right to collective bargaining and prohibits certain employer and union misconduct that interferes with this right.
* The Act defines "supervisor" as an individual with authority to perform certain functions, using independent judgment, in the interest of the employer.
* The Supreme Court in Kentucky River Community Care, Inc. held that professional or technical judgment can still be considered independent judgment for supervisory status.
* The NLRB in Oakwood Healthcare, Inc. defined key terms in the supervisory status test, including "assign," "responsibly to direct," and "independent judgment."
* Section 8(a)(1) of the NLRA prohibits employer interference, restraint, or coercion of employees' collective bargaining rights, including threats of reprisal or force.
* Section 8(b)(1)(A) prohibits union restraint or coercion of employees' collective bargaining rights, including threats of job loss for refusing to join the union.
</summary>

• Banks are central to the financial system and play a vital role in the U.S. economy.
• They are subject to prudential regulation to ensure they are safely profitable and reduce the risk of failure.
• This regulation includes capital requirements, liquidity requirements, and restrictions on permissible activities.
• The 2008-2009 financial crisis threatened the total collapse of the financial system and the real economy.
• Many assert that the crisis revealed weaknesses in the financial regulatory system and that the crisis was caused by excessive risk-taking by banks.
• Congress enacted the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act in response to the crisis, which made significant changes to the banking industry.

• The Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Extension Act of 2007 (P.L. 110-173) was signed into law on December 29, 2007, to extend and modify certain provisions of the Medicare, Medicaid, and State Children's Health Insurance Programs (SCHIP).
• The Act increases the physician payment update factor, modifies the amounts available in the Physician Assistance and Quality Initiative (PAQI) Fund, and extends the Physician Quality Reporting System.
• It also extends the temporary provision that allows independent laboratories providing services to hospitals to continue to bill directly for such services.
• The Act extends the exceptions process for outpatient therapy services and the cost reimbursement for brachytherapy services and therapeutic radiopharmaceuticals.
• It extends reasonable cost reimbursement for clinical laboratory services provided by qualified rural hospitals and the ability of Special Needs Plans (SNPs) to restrict enrollment to one or more class of special needs beneficiaries.
• The Act extends the temporary provision that allows cost-based plans to continue operating in an area with two local or two regional Medicare Advantage plans.
• It also requires the Secretary to use constant volume weighting in the computation of the average sales price (ASP) for Medicare Part B drugs and biologicals.

* **Committee Authority and Operations:**
	+ House committees have broad authority to conduct studies, investigations, and oversight of laws and programs within their jurisdictions.
	+ Committees are required to adopt written rules that conform to House rules and to publish their rules in the Congressional Record.
	+ Committees have the power to subpoena witnesses and documents, hold hearings, and report measures to the House.
* **Committee Meetings and Hearings:**
	+ Committee meetings and hearings are generally open to the public, with certain exceptions for closed sessions.
	+ Committees may vote to close part or all of a hearing or meeting if disclosure of the matters would endanger national security, compromise sensitive law enforcement information, or violate a law or rule of the House.
	+ Committees may also vote to close part or all of a hearing or meeting to discuss whether there is a cause to resume the hearing in closed session.
* **Committee Reports and Oversight:**
	+ Committees are required to report measures to the House promptly and to include certain information in their reports, such as the names of members voting for and against the measure.
	+ Committees are required to conduct oversight of laws and programs within their jurisdictions and to adopt an oversight plan for each Congress.
	+ Committees are authorized to conduct studies and investigations at any time and to incur related expenses.

<summary>
* The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a regional organization with 10 member countries, established in 1967 to promote economic growth, regional peace, and security cooperation.
* ASEAN's key strategic value lies in its geographic position, economic development, and energy reserves, making it a vital partner for the United States and other major powers.
* The United States has deep-seated interests in Southeast Asia, including maritime security, democracy promotion, and trade liberalization, but has been criticized for not engaging sufficiently with ASEAN.
* The Obama Administration has taken steps to increase engagement with ASEAN, including appointing an ambassador to the organization, acceding to the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation, and holding a U.S.-ASEAN leaders' meeting.
* ASEAN's expansion to include underdeveloped nations has made it difficult for the organization to act in concert, but it has played a key role in promoting regional peace and security.
* The United States and ASEAN share mutual interests in preventing conflict and maintaining regional independence, and America's military posture supports ASEAN's goal of preventing hegemony.
* ASEAN's diplomatic activity has focused on establishing a new Asian economic and strategic group to prevent or ameliorate conflict between external powers, including the United States, China, Japan, and India.
* ASEAN's trade with the United States is dominated by electrical machinery and mechanical appliances, and the United States is ASEAN's fourth-largest trading partner.
* ASEAN has been pursuing closer economic ties with key Asian nations through bilateral trade agreements and discussions about a larger, Asia-based free trade area.
* The United States has not agreed to a formal free trade agreement with ASEAN, but there have been discussions about a possible U.S.-ASEAN FTA.
</summary>

<summary>
* Cuba has been on the U.S. state sponsors of terrorism list since 1982.
* Being on the list restricts trade, aid, and other benefits.
* Cuba's retention on the list has been debated, with some advocating for its removal.
* The U.S. added Cuba to the list due to its support for terrorist groups in Latin America.
* Cuba's continued presence on the list is debated, with some arguing it's a Cold War relic.
* Critics point to Cuba's history of supporting revolutionary movements and hosting fugitives.
* Supporters of Cuba's removal argue it's no longer actively supporting terrorism.
* The U.S. has not responded to Cuba's offers for a bilateral agreement to fight terrorism.
</summary>

• The Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) is a separate tax calculation on a broader tax base than the regular tax, designed to ensure that high-income individuals pay at least some minimum amount of tax.
• The AMT base includes certain itemized deductions, the standard deduction, and personal exemptions, while the regular tax base does not.
• The AMT has a lower exemption amount that is not indexed to inflation, leading to an increasing number of taxpayers being subject to it over time.
• In 1987, about 140,000 returns paid the AMT, but by 1999, this number had increased to 823,000, and it is projected to reach 9 million by 2009.
• The AMT is particularly affecting middle and upper-middle income individuals, with the share of taxpayers on the AMT in the $75,000 to $100,000 income bracket increasing from 1% to 20% between 1998 and 2008.
• Tax cuts that reduce regular tax liabilities but do not also alter the AMT will increase the number of taxpayers on the AMT and cause some or all of the tax cut not to be received by certain families.

• The Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies (THUD) Appropriations Subcommittees fund DOT, HUD, and related agencies.
• DOT's programs support highways, transit, airports, and rail infrastructure, while overseeing safety in all transportation modes.
• HUD's programs address housing problems for low-income households, including rental assistance and community development grants.
• The FAA, a DOT sub-agency, operates the U.S. air traffic control system and employs over 80% of DOT's workforce.
• HUD's FHA insures mortgages for homebuyers and developers of multifamily rental buildings.
• Title III of the THUD bill funds related agencies, including the Access Board, Federal Maritime Commission, and National Transportation Safety Board.
• The Surface Transportation Board, formerly a DOT agency, is now independent and appears in Title III of the THUD bill.
• The THUD bill's funding is primarily discretionary, with some contract authority and emergency appropriations.

<summary>
* The U.S. and India have a "global partnership" but differ on Iran policy.
* India has a strategic partnership with Iran, including energy cooperation.
* U.S. concerns about India's Iran relations include defense ties and energy deals.
* India has voted with the U.S. on Iran nuclear issues at the IAEA and UNSC.
* India has restricted nuclear exports to Iran due to UN sanctions.
* India and Iran cooperate in Afghanistan to counter extremism.
</summary>

• **Current Situation and Concerns**: Low farm milk prices and declining dairy farm incomes in 2009 have renewed interest in imposing new import barriers on milk protein concentrates (MPCs) in the U.S. MPCs, which include casein and caseinates, are used in various food products and have limited or no trade restrictions. Major foreign suppliers of MPCs to the U.S. market would likely seek compensation under World Trade Organization (WTO) rules for new U.S. restrictions on MPC imports.
• **U.S. Dairy Industry and MPC Imports**: The U.S. dairy industry produces very little casein or milk protein concentrates, partly due to federal dairy policies that encourage the production of nonfat dry milk. U.S. imports of dairy products were valued at just over $3 billion in 2008, with MPCs and casein/caseinates combined representing 35% of total import value. Major foreign suppliers include New Zealand, Australia, and the European Union.
• **Historical and Current Import Restrictions**: Until 1995, imports of almost all dairy products were subject to section 22 import quotas, which were converted to tariff rate quotas (TRQs) under the 1995 WTO Uruguay Round Agreement on Agriculture. MPCs and casein imports had not been restricted under section 22 and were not subject to TRQs or licensing requirements. In 2002, the U.S. Customs Service received a petition to change the tariff classification of MPCs, but it was rejected. In 2009, legislation was introduced to limit imports of MPCs, casein, and caseinates by establishing TRQs.
• **Potential Impact and Compensation**: Enactment of the proposed legislation would likely entail the United States entering into compensation negotiations with WTO member countries that are major suppliers of MPCs to the U.S. market. The aggregate amount of compensation could be an estimated $500 million. The main issue in Article XXVIII negotiations would be quota allocation. The potential price impact of imposing TRQs depends on the level of farm prices relative to the implied level of support under the Dairy Product Price Support Program (DPPSP). Stricter import controls could result in reduced government purchases of dairy products and lower outlays, or potentially affect farm milk prices if product prices remain above purchase prices in the DPPSP

* <summary>
	+ Serbia's new government, formed in 2012, is led by the Serbian Progressive Party (SNS) and the Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS), with Ivica Dacic as Prime Minister and Tomislav Nikolic as President.
	+ The government's main challenges include addressing the economic crisis, fighting corruption, and normalizing relations with Kosovo.
	+ Serbia's relations with the EU are key to its foreign policy, with the goal of EU membership, while ties with the U.S. are improving but remain clouded by the Kosovo issue.
* </summary>

* <summary>
* The Supreme Court decided four search and seizure cases during its October 2012 term.
* Florida v. Jardines involved the use of a drug-sniffing dog at a private residence, with the Court ruling that such use constitutes a search under the Fourth Amendment.
* Florida v. Harris concerned the use of a drug-detection dog's alert as probable cause for a vehicle search, with the Court reversing the Florida Supreme Court's decision.
* </summary>

<summary>
* The federal government has supported energy storage and electric power system technology since the 1970s, with a focus on improving grid reliability, efficiency, and security.
* The Department of Energy's Office of Electricity Delivery and Energy Reliability (OE) leads efforts to modernize the electric grid, aiming to provide reliable, affordable, and clean electricity to consumers.
* OE's mission is guided by the Quadrennial Technology Review and the Grid Modernization Multi-Year Program Plan, with a vision for a future grid that supports economic growth and energy innovation.
* OE's programs are aligned with the Obama Administration's priorities, including increasing grid resilience, managing risks, and deploying advanced control capabilities.
* OE's FY2017 budget request sought to support grid modernization and cybersecurity initiatives, including new programs for state distribution-level reform, state energy assurance, and a grid institute.
</summary>

* The Commemorative Works Act (CWA) of 1986 governs the establishment of commemorative works in the District of Columbia and its environs, aiming to preserve the integrity of the L'Enfant and McMillan plans for the city.
* The CWA divides the District into three areas for memorial placement: the Reserve, Area I, and Area II, with different standards for memorial placement in each area.
* The CWA established a 24-step process for creating a memorial, involving legislation, site selection, design approval, fundraising, construction, and dedication.

* <summary>S. 1796, America's Healthy Future Act of 2009, aims to restructure the private health insurance market, set minimum standards for health benefits, and provide financial assistance to certain individuals and small employers.</summary>

<summary>
* **Purpose of High Risk Pools**: High risk pools (HRPs) are state-established programs designed to provide health insurance coverage to individuals who cannot obtain or afford private health insurance due to preexisting health conditions.
* **Eligibility**: Eligible individuals include those who have been denied coverage, received quotes higher than standard rates, or have preexisting conditions excluded from coverage. Many states also allow HIPAA-eligible persons to enroll.
* **State Discretion**: States have considerable discretion in establishing and operating HRPs, including covered benefits, eligibility requirements, preexisting condition exclusion periods, and funding sources.
* **Funding**: States fund HRPs through premiums, assessments on insurers, general revenue, and other state sources. Federal grants are also available to help cover operating losses.
* **Benefits**: Benefits offered by HRPs vary by state but generally reflect coverage available in the private nongroup market. Most plans have lifetime maximums on benefits and exclude coverage for preexisting conditions for 6-12 months.
* **Enrollment**: Enrollment in state HRPs varies significantly, with average participation ranging from a high of 27,187 in Minnesota to a low of 265 in Florida in December 2009.
* **Federal Grants**: The federal government provides grants to states to establish and operate HRPs. Grants are awarded based on state uninsured population, high risk pool population, and operational losses.
* **PPACA and Temporary High Risk Pools**: The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) requires the establishment of a temporary high risk pool program prior to 2014, providing coverage to certain individuals with preexisting conditions who have been uninsured for six or more months.
* **State Options for PPACA HRPs**: States can choose to run their own HRPs or elect to have the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) operate the program in their states. The majority of states contracted to operate their own HRPs, while HHS administers the HRPs in 21 states under the Pre-Existing Condition Insurance Plan (PCIP) name.
</summary>

* The Civil Reserve Air Fleet (CRAF) is a program that provides airlift support to the Department of Defense (DOD) during emergencies.
* The program is voluntary and involves commercial airlines committing a portion of their fleet to DOD in exchange for peacetime business.
* The CRAF has been activated twice in its history, most recently during Operation Iraqi Freedom.

• **NTIA's Role**: The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) is a U.S. Department of Commerce agency that serves as the principal advisor to the President on telecommunications and information policy.
• **Domestic and International Responsibilities**: NTIA works on both domestic and international telecommunications and information technology policies, representing the U.S. in international negotiations and coordinating with other federal agencies.
• **Spectrum Management**: NTIA manages the use of the radio spectrum by federal agencies, acting as a facilitator and mediator in negotiations among agencies and working with the FCC on spectrum access and policy.
• **Internet Policy**: NTIA leads and participates in interagency efforts to develop Internet policy, playing a lead role in the Department of Commerce's Internet Policy Task Force.
• **Grant Programs**: NTIA administers grant programs, including the Broadband Technology Opportunities Program (BTOP) and the Public Safety Interoperable Communications (PSIC) grant program, to further technology deployment and advancement of national priorities.
• **FirstNet**: NTIA is responsible for establishing requirements for a $135 million grant program to help states plan for participation in a new, nationwide public safety broadband network, FirstNet.
• **Policy Administration**: NTIA's policies and programs are administered through various offices, including the Office of Spectrum Management (OSM), Office of Policy Analysis and Development (OPAD), Office of International Affairs (OIA), Institute for Telecommunication Sciences (ITS), and Office of Telecommunications and Information Applications (OTIA).
• **Funding**: For FY2012, NTIA received $45.6 million for salaries and expenses, an increase of 9.6% over the previous year but 18.4% less than the Administration's request. The Administration requested $55.8 million for FY2013.
• **Spectrum for Mobile Broadband**: NTIA supports the Administration's goal of increasing spectrum capacity for mobile broadband by 500 MHz, and has produced a 10-year plan and timetable identifying bands of spectrum that might be available for commercial wireless broadband service.

• **Electric Reliability Act of 2005**: This subtitle aims to improve reliability of the U.S. bulk power system by providing federal jurisdiction over activities required to support reliability.
• **FERC-Certified Electric Reliability Organization (ERO)**: FERC is required to establish an ERO within 180 days of enactment, which will develop and enforce reliability standards for the bulk power system.
• **Reliability Standards**: The ERO will create reliability standards, approved by FERC, covering cybersecurity protection. Penalties can be imposed for violations, and FERC can order compliance.
